q3.value: Research has shown that alternating between topics when studying can enhance learning and retention. However, no research has explored how mixing up topics when learning key-term definitions affects learning. The current research will explore how mixing up topics versus not mixing up topics from the discipline of cognitive psychology affects learning and subsequent retention. Results from this research will help us come to a better understanding of how different study schedules affect later memory.

q4.value: We predict that practicing key-term definitions from two content areas within cognitive psychology in an interleaved fashion versus a blocked fashion will lead to higher final test performance.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: interleaved, blocked-spaced, or blocked-massed. Group assignment will be manipulated between subjects. Group assignment will be the independent variable (3 levels) and performance on the final (cued recall) test will be the dependent variable.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the North Dakota State University student listserv; participation in this listserv is voluntary. The email announcement will include a brief description of the proposed research and interested individuals will be told to contact the research team. Consent will be obtained when participants enter the laboratory for the Session 1. All consent forms will be obtained by research assistants working in the lab. Only the research assistant on duty at that time will see the consent form. They will indicate their agreement to participate by signing the consent form. Participants will have time to review the consent form and ask questions before signing. All participants will receive a copy of the consent form for their reference. Participants will receive $25 after the completion of Session 1 (about 30 minutes), Session 2 (about 30 minutes), and Session 3 (about 15 minutes).

q13.value: The intended sample size is approximately 200 undergraduates, which is based on the sample size used in a prior study that used a similar design (Interleaving with Definitions).

q14.value: To determine sample size, an a priori power analysis was conducted using G*Power 3.1.9.2 with power set at .80 and α = .05 to detect a medium effect of f = .25, which indicated n = 159. To account for attrition, we will slightly oversample; as such, the research will include approximately 200 participants.

question.value: Group assignment will be the independent variable (i.e., what practice schedule participants use to learn the key term definitions) and will be manipulated between subjects. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the interleaved group, the blocked/massed group, or the blocked/spaced group. This group assignment will determine when participants engage in initial study and practice of the key terms. For the interleaved group, participants will engage in initial study for all 12 key terms and practice each key term twice during Session 1, and practice each key term three times during Session 2; key terms will be practiced in an alternating fashion (e.g., one term from memory, followed by one term from development, followed by one term from memory, etc.). For the blocked/massed group, participants will engage in initial study twice for 6 key terms from one topic and practice each key term five times during Session 1, and engage in initial study twice for 6 key terms from the other topic and practice each key term five times during Session 2. For the blocked/spaced group, participants will engage in initial study for all 12 key terms and practice each key term twice during Session 1, and practice each key term three times during Session 2; key terms will be practiced in a blocked fashion (e.g., all memory terms, followed by all developmental terms).

Final test performance will be the dependent variable. All participants will complete a final, cued-recall test during Session 3. The final test will be self-paced and no feedback will be provided. Participants will also answer a metacognitive reflection question about whether they would interleave or block their practice of key-term definitions for an upcoming exam and provide rationale for why they would choose their approach.
N/A

Data will be analyzed via a one-way ANOVA; group assignment will be the independent variable (3 levels) and performance on the final test will be the dependent variable. Follow-up t-tests will be conducted if necessary.

q21.value: We will set the threshold of determining significance at alpha = .05

q22.value: Participants will be excluded due to attrition (i.e., they do not show up for all three sessions) or non-compliance (e.g., not following task instructions, such as not providing a response when prompted).

q23.value: If participants are missing data from any of the three sessions, they will not be included in analyses.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

other.value: We will exclude from our analyses any cases in which a person (a) reports a relationship length greater than his or her age (b) self-reports his or her age as being less than 18 or greater than 65, or (c) fails our attention checks.

sample.value: The second half of the dataset includes 2460 cases.

analyses.value:
First, we will conduct a multiple regression in which attachment to partner (anxiety) is regressed onto attachment to mother (anxiety), relationship length, age, and the three two-way interactions between these variables.  We will conduct a similar multiple regression in which attachment to partner (avoidance) is regressed onto attachment to mother (avoidance), relationship length, age, and the three two-way interactions between these variables.

We will conduct additional analyses of a similar fashion in which relationship satisfaction will serve as the dependent variable.  Relationship satisfaction will be regressed onto attachment to mother (anxiety), relationship length, age, and the three two-way interactions between these variables.  Similarly, relationship satisfaction will be regressed onto attachment to mother (avoidance), relationship length, age, and the three two-way interactions between these variables.

All analyses will be conducted in R.  Below is a section of sample R code.

results = lm(anxiety_partner ~ anxiety_mother + relationship_length + age + anxiety_mother:relationship_length + anxiety_mother:age + relationship_length:age, data=data)

results1 = lm(avoidance_partner ~ avoidance_mother + relationship_length + age + avoidance_mother:relationship_length + avoidance_mother:age + relationship_length:age, data=data)
	
results2 = lm(relationship_satisfaction ~ anxiety_mother + relationship_length + age + anxiety_mother:relationship_length + 	anxiety_mother:age + relationship_length:age, data=data)

results3 = lm(relationship_satisfaction ~ avoidance_mother + 	relationship_length + age + avoidance_mother:relationship_length + avoidance_mother:age + relationship_length:age, data=data)

The variables attachment to partner (anxiety and avoidance), attachment to mother 	(anxiety and avoidance), age, and relationship satisfaction will all be in z-score form.

To investigate whether relationship length moderates the relationship between attachment 	to father and attachment to partner, we will conduct a similar set of analyses to those 	described above with attachment to father (anxiety and avoidance) replacing attachment 	to mother.  We will also investigate whether relationship length moderates the relationship between attachment to father and relationship satisfaction in a similar fashion. The R code will remain the same, again with the exception of anxiety_father and avoidance_father replacing anxiety_mother and anxiety_mother. The variables attachment to partner (anxiety and avoidance), attachment to father (anxiety and avoidance), age, and relationship satisfaction will all be in z-score form.

dependent.value:
There are two dependent variables of interest- attachment to partner and relationship satisfaction.  

Attachment to partner was measured using the partner scale of the ECR-RS (Fraley et al., 2011).  This scale includes both items that assess attachment anxiety and items that assess attachment avoidance.  Each item is rated on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree) scale.

Relationship satisfaction was measured using the Investment Model Scale (Rusbult, Martz, & Agnew, 1998).  This scale assesses four domains of relationship functioning including three items which pertain to one’s satisfaction in his or her relationship.  This scale was only administered to respondents if they indicated that they were in a relationship at the time of assessment.

conditions.value: There are no conditions.  This is a correlational (cross-sectional) design.  The predictor variables of interest are (a) attachment to mother (anxiety and avoidance), (b) attachment to father (anxiety and avoidance), and (c) relationship length.  We will also include age as a covariate.

hypothesis.value:
The main question we wish to address is how parental attachment is related to relationship functioning as a function of relationship length.  There are at least two ways attachment dynamics could play out.  One possibility is that people’s representations of their parents become less relevant for relationship functioning as that relationship matures (as relationship length increases).  This perspective predicts that there will be an interaction between relationship length and parental attachment in predicting relationship functioning.  An alternative possibility is that people’s representations of their parents are relevant for understanding relationship functioning for both newer and more established relationships.  This perspective predicts main effects for parental attachment on relationship functioning but no interaction with relationship length.

We will examine these possibilities focusing on relationship satisfaction and romantic attachment as relationship outcome variables.  We will examine both mother and father attachment as our parental attachment variables, but we are primarily interested in maternal attachment.

Based on our exploratory analyses, it seems that the latter hypothesis better explains the data.  The confirmatory sample will give us the opportunity to replicate this result.

attributes.title: A School-Level Randomized Controlled Trial of the Impacts of the Reading Is Fundamental (RIF) Books for Ownership Book Distribution Program on Students’ Longitudinal Reading Achievement

q1.value: A School-Level Randomized Controlled Trial of the Impacts of the Reading Is Fundamental (RIF) Books for Ownership Book Distribution Program on Students’ Longitudinal Reading Achievement

q3.value: Though a vast literature suggests that students from high-poverty backgrounds experience profound summer-based reading deficits, research suggests that interventions that target summer learning can help.  Over the past half century, the Books for Ownership (BFO) program has been the long-standing signature program associated with the RIF organization.  The program, which includes a school-based book celebration event—during which the free books are distributed to children—also helps incorporate motivational reading activities into the school reading program, involves parents and the community, and promotes use by schools of Literacy Central, which offers thousands of digital resources tied to the books that RIF offers. These school-based components are designed to help students develop greater interest and engagement in self-directed reading that, in turn, can promote continued engagement in reading after summer dismissal, which ultimately may promote summer and school-year literacy achievement.

q4.value: The primary hypothesis is that school-level random assignment to the BFO treatment will impact the schools' grade 4 students’ Year 3 (fall 2021-22) reading achievement--relative to a no-treatment control group of schools and students--as measured by the school district’s standardized exam.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a school-level randomized trial, with 30 schools assigned to treatment and 30 schools assigned to a no-treatment control condition.  Students in all schools will be tracked longitudinally from grade 2 (in fall 2019-20) through grade 4 (in fall 2021-22).

data.name: Borman Pre-Analysis Plan RIF Miami BFO (LJAF).docx

extra.selectedFileName: Borman Pre-Analysis Plan RIF Miami BFO (LJAF).docx

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Baseline demographic data and baseline student survey data were collected prior to treatment in winter 2019-20.  No survey data have been observed and baseline demographics were looked at only to assess baseline equivalence of treatment and control.

question.value: All students within the 60 schools will participate, unless a parent declares to the district and study team that his/her student "opts out" of the study.

q13.value: A sample of 30 treatment and 30 control schools are included in the sample.  Approximately 5,000 2nd graders across the 60 schools are in the baseline sample.

q14.value: The minimum detectable effect size (MDES) for the proposed study was estimated based on a desired statistical power of .80, an alpha level of p <.05, and a sample of 60 schools with a 50% probability of treatment assignment. In addition, we estimated an intra-cluster correlation (ICC) of .10, and a student- and school-level covariate (pretest) correlation of .80. Given these assumptions, the power analysis indicates that with a sample of 60 schools and 80 students per school we will be able to detect MDESs of d = 0.15 for the proposed student/school sample. This MDES is consistent with prior meta-analytic estimates of summer program effects, ranging from approximately d = 0.09 to d = 0.19.

question.value: Student outcome data provided by the districts will include all standardized reading test scores. from grade 2 through the fall of grade 4.  Also, using a reliable, valid, and age-appropriate survey instrument administered to students during the beginning of the 4th grade in fall 2021-22, we will assess program impacts on: (1) book ownership; (2) amount of reading during the summer; (3) engagement in literacy activities during the summer; and (4) attitudes toward recreational reading.

The student achievement data will be gleaned from the Miami-Dade County Public Schools' fall and spring literacy assessments.  Survey data will assess program impacts on: (1) book ownership; (2) amount of reading during the summer; (3) engagement in literacy activities during the summer; and (4) attitudes toward recreational reading. Book ownership will be measured as one student-specific measure of treatment uptake, and will answer the question: To what extent is the program causing an increase in home-based book ownership among treatment students relative to control students? This question can be answered based on a National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) item: “Some homes have 0 books while others have more than 50 books for kids. About how many books for kids do you have at home?”  
A scale to assess reading amount is adapted from Schaffner, Schiefele, and Ulferts (2013) from Becker et al.’s (2010) questionnaire. In accordance with Becker et al., the Schaffner et al. (2013) scale includes two items referring to reading frequency and one item capturing reading length. To assess reading frequency, the students will be asked how many books they read in their spare time (1 = 0 books, 2 = 1–5 books, 3 = 6–10 books, 4 = 11–20 books, 5 = more than 20 books) and how often they read in their spare time (1 = about once a month, 2 = about once a week, 3 = several times a week, 4 = daily, 5 = several times a day). Reading length will be addressed by asking the students how long they usually read a book without taking a break (1 = 5 minutes, 2 = 15 minutes, 3 = 30 minutes, 4 = 60 minutes, 5 = more than 60 minutes). The scale refers only to reading for enjoyment because this aspect of reading amount is more strongly related to reading motivation and reading comprehension than reading for school (Cox & Guthrie, 2001; Wang & Guthrie, 2004). Statistically significant correlations with aspects of the home literacy environment (e.g., number of books at home) and with intrinsic (but not extrinsic) reading motivation (Schaffner et al., 2013) support the validity of this scale.

The measure of attitudes toward recreational reading will draw on the classic Elementary Reading Attitude Survey (ERAS) developed by McKenna and Kear (1990). We will use the 10-item recreational reading scale, which focuses on reading for fun outside of the school setting. Each item on the ERAS asks how children feel about a specific recreational reading activity. Children respond to each question by circling one of four cartoon-style Garfield cats whose facial expressions range from very happy to very unhappy. This scale includes items such as: “How do you feel about getting a book for a present?” and “How do you feel about reading for fun at home?” McKenna and Kear (1990) administered the survey to 18,138 students in Grades 1 to 6 in 95 school districts throughout 38 states, and the internal reliability coefficient was .82 for the recreational subscale. 

Finally, to supplement the scale of reading volume, children will also be administered questions asking how often they engaged in a series of literacy activities at home. The 10-item Literacy Habits Survey (Paris et al., 2004) has been used with beginning readers from kindergarten to third grade in previous studies, and yielded an internal reliability coefficient of .76 in a recent study by Kim (2007). The survey includes close-ended questions about literacy related activities at home, such as: “How often do you read for fun?” and “How often do you play word games like Scrabble or Hangman?” Children are asked to respond: (1) never or hardly ever, (2) about once a week, or (3) almost every day.
Not applicable.

As our proposed analytical strategy, we will use hierarchical linear models. In this formulation, we account for both student and school-level sources of variability in the outcomes by specifying a two-level hierarchical model that estimates the school-level effect of random assignment to treatment. At level-two of the model, we will estimate the cluster-level impact of BFO treatment assignment on the mean posttest achievement outcome in school j.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the treatment and control outcomes are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: All data will be included and no outliers will be excluded.  Only cases with missing data may be excluded.

q23.value: We will analyze only complete-case information.  If missing pre-post survey data is missing at a rate of 25% or greater for the total student sample, then we will define two separate analytical samples: (1) an administrative-data-only sample, having complete data on the baseline covariate and achievement outcome; and (2) a student-survey sample, having complete data on the baseline covariate and on the four student survey outcomes.

Reading length will be addressed by asking the students how long they usually read a book without taking a break (1 = 5 minutes, 2 = 15 minutes, 3 = 30 minutes, 4 = 60 minutes, 5 = more than 60 minutes). The scale refers only to reading for enjoyment because this aspect of reading amount is more strongly related to reading motivation and reading comprehension than reading for school (Cox & Guthrie, 2001; Wang & Guthrie, 2004). Statistically significant correlations with aspects of the home literacy environment (e.g., number of books at home) and with intrinsic (but not extrinsic) reading motivation (Schaffner et al., 2013) support the validity of this scale.

The measure of attitudes toward recreational reading will draw on the classic Elementary Reading Attitude Survey (ERAS) developed by McKenna and Kear (1990). We will use the 10-item recreational reading scale, which focuses on reading for fun outside of the school setting. Each item on the ERAS asks how children feel about a specific recreational reading activity. Children respond to each question by circling one of four cartoon-style Garfield cats whose facial expressions range from very happy to very unhappy. This scale includes items such as: “How do you feel about getting a book for a present?” and “How do you feel about reading for fun at home?” McKenna and Kear (1990) administered the survey to 18,138 students in Grades 1 to 6 in 95 school districts throughout 38 states, and the internal reliability coefficient was .82 for the recreational subscale. 

Finally, to supplement the scale of reading volume, children will also be administered questions asking how often they engaged in a series of literacy activities at home. The 10-item Literacy Habits Survey (Paris et al., 2004) has been used with beginning readers from kindergarten to third grade in previous studies, and yielded an internal reliability coefficient of .76 in a recent study by Kim (2007). The survey includes close-ended questions about literacy related activities at home, such as: “How often do you read for fun?” and “How often do you play word games like Scrabble or Hangman?” Children are asked to respond: (1) never or hardly ever, (2) about once a week, or (3) almost every day.
registration_responses.q18.question: Not applicable.
registration_responses.q19.question: As our proposed analytical strategy, we will use hierarchical linear models. In this formulation, we account for both student and school-level sources of variability in the outcomes by specifying a two-level hierarchical model that estimates the school-level effect of random assignment to treatment. At level-two of the model, we will estimate the cluster-level impact of BFO treatment assignment on the mean posttest achievement outcome in school j.

name.value: A terror management model of disease communication and preventative behavior: testing the model in the case of coronavirus

other.value:
Moderator variables:
We hypothesize that reminders of coronavirus will motivate intentions to attend work while sick primarily for those whose worldview values work and/or derive self-esteem from work. Thus, it is expected that the effect will be strongest among those who strongly endorse a Protestant Work Ethic and those who indicate that their self-esteem depends on their work. These will be measured with three items from the Protestant Work Ethic scale, and 7 items adapted from the Contingencies of Self-worth scale. These are included below.
PWE:
1.	Life would be more meaningful if we had more leisure time.
2.	I feel uneasy when there is little work for me to do.
3.	A distaste for hard work usually reflects a weakness of character.
Contigencies of Self-worth – Adapted 
1.	When I do well at my job, I feel good about myself
2.	My self-worth is based on how well I do at my job
3.	My self-esteem is unrelated to how I perform at my job
4.	Knowing that I have succeeded whatever task I am given at work is important to me
5.	Whenever I succeed at my job, my sense of self-respect gets a boost
6.	I could not respect myself if I did poorly at my job
7.	I do not care if I am good at my job or not


Mediator variables:
While death-related cognitions are hypothesized to underlie the relationship between reminders of coronavirus and intentions to attend work while sick, this is not addressed in the current study. When death-related cognitions are the mediating variable, measurement of mediation approaches can be problematic (see Hayes & Schimel, 2018). Causal chain approaches will be taken in the future if this initial effect is observed.

More analyses:
A number of secondary analyses will be conducted including:
•	Testing whether a delay is necessary for effects to emerge following reminders of coronavirus 
•	Bivariate correlations among all study variables
•	Including a number of demographic and other variables as potential covariates and moderators. These variables include but are not limited to association between coronavirus and death, health insurance status, subjective health status, etc. 
•	Exploratory analyses on just world beliefs
Secondary analyses that are not listed here may be conducted based on unforeseen patterns in the results. As these will lead to, by definition, unforeseen results, future replications will need to be done.

sample.value: We will recruit participants from Mturk. All American participants will be allowed to participate. Based on budgetary restraints, we aim for 150 participants per condition. To achieve this, we will recruit 600 participants. If, due to attrition and the application of the exclusion criteria outlined below, conditions are left with less than 150 participants, then we will recruit more participants until reaching the target number. All analyses listed above will be conducted after the entire sample (N > 600) is collected.

analyses.value: To test whether intentions to attend work while sick differ by condition, first a one-way ANOVA will be conducted. Potential differences between conditions will be examined using post hoc tests. To further test for moderation by Protestant work ethic and contingencies of self-worth, regression analyses will be conducted using the Process module in SPSS (Hayes, 2018). Potential interactions will be examined using simple slopes and predicted means.

outliers.value:
We will exclude outliers detected using standard procedures. Additionally, participants will be recruited if:
1.	They complete the study in less than three minutes
2.	They miss the attention check. In the just world beliefs scale, there is an item that states “Leave this item blank”. Participants who answer this question with any response will be considered to have failed the attention check and will be dropped from analyses. 
3.	They indicate that they had trouble with understanding the survey.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable consists of a series of adapted items (also used in a previous study) intended to measure intentions to attend work while sick. These are measured on a scale of 1-7 and are included below:
1.	If you feel sick, how likely are you to take time off from work?
2.	If you feel sick in the future, how likely are you to take time off from work?
3.	If you have a strong cough, how likely are you to take time off from work?
4.	If a doctor tells you that you are too sick to work how likely are you to take time off from work?
5.	How sick would you have to be in order to take time off from work?
6.	If coronavirus arrived in your country (not your city), you would come to work as normal.
7.	If coronavirus arrived in your city, you would come to work as normal.

conditions.value: This study has 2 independent variables. First, participants will read either a passage about coronavirus which mentions its symptoms and predictions of spread from the CDC or a neutral (i.e., unrelated to coronavirus and/or death) passage adapted from a recent news story. Second, participants will either complete a delay task (e.g., affect scale) or not.

hypothesis.value: Building from terror management theory, the present study is testing one component of a theoretical model of disease communication and preventative behavior. The main question of this study is whether, to the extent to which exposure to information about coronavirus elicits death-related thoughts, those who derive self-esteem from their work will respond to coronavirus reminders with increased intentions to attend work while sick.

attributes.title: The Self-Enhancement versus Self-Verification of Facial Identity
attributes.description: Participants imagine possible ways their face might be, in terms of being more or less attractive and familiar. Their reactions afford evidence of the operation and strength of the motives to self-enhance and self-verify.

q1.value: Facial Self-Motives 2: Envisaging the Desirability and Effects of Hypothetical Face Modifications, Thereby Pitting Self-Enhancing Strivings for Facial Attractiveness Against Self-Verifying Strivings for Facial Familiarity

q3.value:
This is Study 2 in a series of studies. Their overall purpose is to test whether people are motivated to verify as well as to enhance their facial identity, and to what extent they are motivated to do one versus the other. The motive to self-enhance is presumed to be captured by striving for facial attractiveness: having an attractive face affords a positive evaluation whereas having an unattractive face affords a negative evaluation. The motive to self-verify is presumed to be captured by striving for facial familiarity: having a familiar face affords a sense that one's life and world are predictable, controllable, and coherent whereas having an unfamiliar face affords a sense that they are not. 

Study 2 has participants to engage in two main tasks. 

First, participants envisage ways their face might look, and provide desirability ratings for these possibilities (Face Desirability Ratings). In particular, they imagine four distinct ways their face might look, and thereafter to indicate how much they ideally want their face to look like this. These four ways orthogonalize levels of attractiveness and familiarity. In the Absolute Condition, these four ways are: (a) Entirely Familiar & Amazingly Attractive; (b) Entirely Familiar & Hideously Unattractive; (c) Altogether Unfamiliar & Amazingly Attractive; and (d) Altogether Unfamiliar & Hideously Unattractive. In the Relative Condition, these four ways are: (a*) Entirely Familiar & Amazingly Attractive; (e) Entirely Familiar & As Attractive As It Is Now; (c*) Altogether Unfamiliar & Amazingly Attractive; and (f) Altogether Unfamiliar & As Attractive As it Is Now. (*=identical)

Second, participants envisage ways their face might look, and estimate the psychological effects of these possibilities being true (Face Effect Ratings). In particular, they imagine four distinct ways their face might look, and thereafter to indicate, via three separate ratings, how they would feel about their ability to "X" their world and life, where "X" is, respectively, "predict", "control", and"make sense of". The four distinct ways correspond to those for the desirability ratings, in the Absolute Condition and the Relative Condition. 

The purpose of having two versions, with different ranges for attractiveness, is take account of the fact that the logical zero-point of facial self-enhancement (Hideously Unattractive) may not be psychologically relevant zero-point, which is liable to be shifted in the direction of the status quo point (As Attractive As It Is Now), but whose exactly location is difficult to determine. However, the psychologically relevant zero-point is likely to lie somewhere in the interval between the logical zero-point and status quo point, such that the results of both versions of the study, pertaining to the interval extremes, will enable stronger conclusions to be drawn and more informed estimates of relative self-motive strength to be made. A similar distinction in other studies in the series.

In addition, participants are asked to indicate, at the beginning of the study, the extent to which they perceive their face to be attractive and familiar, and the extent to which they desire for their face to be attractive and familiar. These perceptions and desires can themselves serve as straightforward indications of how people think they stand in terms of these identity-relevant facial characteristics, and how much they want to facially self-enhance and self-verify in both an absolute sense and a relative sense. In addition, these perceptions and desires are liable to moderate the magnitude of the other findings.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 0 (H0)--so dubbed as it regarded as near self-evident--is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity.

Hypothesis 1 (H1) is that people will strive to verify their facial identity.

Hypothesis 2 (H2) is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity more than they strive to verify it.

These three hypotheses yield several predictions.

FIRST: As regards the extent to which participants' initial self-reported desire for their face to be attractive and familiar, we predict that they will want it to be more attractive than not (H0), and more familiar than not (H1), but also to want the former more than they want the latter (H2).

(Moderation: We predict that this will also be the case even when perceptions of facial attractiveness and familiarity are controlled for. In this regard, we do not predict any definite simple correlation between the perception of one's facial attractiveness and the desire to be facially attractive: although a deficiency of facial attractiveness might amplify desire for its improvement, it might also promote a downgrading of facial attractiveness, leading to a "draw". As for the correlation between facial familiarity and desire for facial familiarity, a lack of variation in the former case is liable to constrain correlations to the point of uninformativeness.)

(Ancillary: We predict that perceptions of attractiveness will be above the midpoint of the scale*, and, fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will also be above the midpoint of the scale. We also predict, again fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will be higher than perceptions of attractiveness. By default, most faces are surely nearly maximal in familiarity; but the motive to self-enhance is unlikely to be strong enough to convince nearly everyone that they are nearly maximal in attractiveness.)

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it reflects actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.

-------

Next, for both Face Desirability Ratings and Face Effect Ratings--and in both the Absolute Version and the Relative Version of the study--we make predictions (i) within each of the four conditions, and (ii) between those four conditions, taking the form of simple or competitive self-enhancing effects (involving attractiveness) and self-verifying effects (involving familiarity).

SECOND: Face Desirability Ratings

--Between-condition predictions

In terms of Face Desirability Ratings, we predict: 

An overall effect of attractiveness (H0), such that faces that are Amazingly Attractive are more desired than faces that are Hideously Unattractive (Absolute Version) or As They Are Now (Relative Version).

An overall effect of familiarity (H1), such that faces that are Entirely Familiar are more desired than faces that are Altogether Unfamiliar (Absolute & Relative Versions).

The above overall effect of attractiveness will exceed the above overall effect of familiarity (H2)

We also predict that, at each of the two levels of familiarity, there will be effect of attractiveness (H0), and that at each of the two levels of attractiveness, there will be an effect of familiarity (H1). Specifically, we predict that, for the conditions labelled above, in the  Absolute Version & Relative Version alike, the following differences will obtain:

H0: (a) > (b), (c) > (d); (a) > (e), (c) > (f)
H1: (a) > (c), (b) > (d); (e) > (f)

We also predict that, in conditions pitting attractiveness against familiarity, the former will prevail, in the Absolute Version & Relative Version alike:

H2: (c) > (b) and (c) > (e)

(Ancillary: We predict a further interactive effect, which is independent of our main hypotheses. It is that the effect of attractiveness will be stronger for familiar faces [or equivalently that the effect of familiarity will be stronger for attractive faces]. We make this prediction because, in addition to familiarity and attractiveness being desiderata in themselves, having a familiar face is liable to increase the self-relevance of having an attractive or unattractive face, and having an unfamiliar face is liable to decrease the self-relevance of having it, because one is rendered, respectively, more or less recognizable as oneself.)

--Within-condition predictions:

We predict that participants WILL generally desire the following facial outcomes, more than they do not desire them:

(a) Entirely Familiar & Amazingly Attractive (consistent with H0 and H1)
(e) Entirely Familiar & As Attractive As It Is Now (consistent with H0 and H1) *

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it depends on actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.

In addition, we predict that participants will generally NOT desire the following facial outcomes, more than they do desire them

(b) Entirely Familiar & Hideously Unattractive (supportive of H0 and H2)
(c) Altogether Unfamiliar & Amazingly Attractive (supportive of H1, and perhaps undermining of H2)

(d) Altogether Unfamiliar & Hideously Unattractive  (consistent with H0 and H1)
(f) Altogether Unfamiliar & As Attractive As it Is Now  (consistent with H0 and perhaps undermining of H2)

(Moderation 1: We predict that any advantage for self-enhancing strivings above will be more apparent in the Absolute condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is wider, than in the Relative condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is smaller. If H2 is falsified, then it is more likely to be falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition, or to be more strongly falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition.)

(Moderation 2: We predict that that the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings, in the direction of the former, will be positively related to participant's self-reported desires for their face to be attractive, and negatively related to their self-reported desires for their face to be familiar.)

(Moderation 3: We predict that self-enhancing strivings will be stronger (i) in women and (ii) in younger people, with such factors possibly combining synergistically. This is because, for evolutionary and lifespan reasons respectively, facial attractiveness has greater normative value for women and younger people. )

THIRD: Face Effect Ratings

In general, our predictions for Face Effect Ratings generally parallel for Face Desirability Ratings. To save space, they will not be reiterated.

Note, however, two important points.

First, there are three Face Effect Ratings for each predicted effect. These ratings are liable to be highly internally consistent, and a composite index thereof--referred to as "tractability", the degree to which people feel they are able to get a "handle" (i.e., gain "traction") on their life and world, by feeling it to be predictable, controllable, and coherent--will be derived. The three ratings will also be analyzed separately, but the same predictions are made in respect of all of them, and no predictions are made about differences in relative magnitude.

Second, the self-verification perspective holds that verification strivings are ultimately in the service of augmenting or maintain a sense of tractability. However, the possibility also arises, for several reasons, that self-enhancement strivings might do the same (e.g., the illusion of control is touted as one of the main examples of self-enhancement bias). However, the hypothesis that self-enhancement strivings, when satisfied, augment feelings of tractability even more than self-verification strivings, when satisfied, is perhaps surprising, given the existing view that the motives to self-enhance and self-verify compete, and that the latter sometimes dominate the former precisely in order to shore up feelings of tractability.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: As regards the allocation to the Absolute Version and Relative Version of the study, these being between-subject, participants will NOT know the treatment group to which they have been assigned. Likewise, researcher will not know which participants have been assigned to which treatment group.

question.value:
Note that the study has an observational and experimental elements.

Initial inquiries as to participants' perception of their facial attractiveness and familiarity, and their desire for facial attractiveness and familiarity, being analyzed in themselves, reflect a cross-sectional or observational design.

Otherwise, the study features an experimental design, sometimes in which the variables above features as predictors or covariates.

Overall, the experimental design of the study is mixed. The key comparisons are manipulated within-group. As mentioned earlier, these four conditions orthogonally cross attractiveness, at higher or lower levels, with familiarity, at higher or lower levels. Analyses are conducted on two sets of measures (which are not themselves compared): Face Desirability Ratings and Face Effect Ratings. These four within-groups conditions are, in each case, presented in randomized order. The version of the study administered serves as the between-group variable. In the Absolute Version of the study, the relevant attractiveness extremes are Hideously Unattractive and Amazingly Attractive; in the Relative Version of the study, the attractiveness extremes are As Attractive As You Are Now and Amazingly Attractive. In both the Absolute Version and the Relative version, the two familiarity extremes are Altogether Unfamiliar and Entirely Familiar.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be crowdsourced online using Amazon's Mechanical Turk platform in conjunction with TurkPrime. In recompense for a small fee ($.40), participants will be directed to the University of Southampton's local online research software iSurvey. There, they will click on a link for the study, read an information sheet, indicate their consent, complete one of several previously described versions of the study, read the debriefing, and receive the Completion Code they required to access payment on the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform. We will limit participants to those above the age of 18, and from the English-speaking Western countries of the USA, Canada, the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, Australia, and New Zealand. On the platform, participants will be required to have a hit approval rate of greater than 90%, and to have completed between 50 and 500,000 previous hits. In addition, participants will be excluded from completed any other study that is part of the Project, will be excluded if they have completed any other such study (e.g., if studies are run simultaneously). Recruitment of the 450 participants is expected to be brisk (within a week). Any participants showing signs of unearnest participation (e.g., taking part multiple times, providing nonsensical responses, not reporting the completion code) will be flagged for exclusion, flagged as problematic participants on MTurk, and possibly have their payment blocked.

q13.value:
We plan to collect 450 participants. 

Of these, half will be allocated to the Absolute Version, and half to the Relative Version.

q14.value:
We expect to end up with a sample of about 400 usable participants, after excluding problematic cases.

This would entail about 200 usable participants per condition.

As the main analyses are within-participants, such numbers offer ample statistical power to make critical comparisons.

The between-participants comparisons (200 vs 200) offer less, but still ample, statistical power.

In particular, for a modest effect size of d = .3 (which we think many of our effects are liable to markedly exceed), we would be able to detect at a p< .01 level of significance (which use use to control our multiple comparisons) a within-group difference with N = 200 with a power probability of .9486 (rising to .9997 for a subset of analyses with N = 400).

In addition, for a modest effect size of d = .3, we would be able to detect at a p< .01 level of significance (which use use to control our multiple comparisons) a between-group difference with N = 400 with a power probability of .9513.

q15.value: Not relevant. We will stop after 450 participants.

registration_responses.q1: Facial Self-Motives 2: Envisaging the Desirability and Effects of Hypothetical Face Modifications, Thereby Pitting Self-Enhancing Strivings for Facial Attractiveness Against Self-Verifying Strivings for Facial Familiarity
registration_responses.q3:
This is Study 2 in a series of studies. Their overall purpose is to test whether people are motivated to verify as well as to enhance their facial identity, and to what extent they are motivated to do one versus the other. The motive to self-enhance is presumed to be captured by striving for facial attractiveness: having an attractive face affords a positive evaluation whereas having an unattractive face affords a negative evaluation. The motive to self-verify is presumed to be captured by striving for facial familiarity: having a familiar face affords a sense that one's life and world are predictable, controllable, and coherent whereas having an unfamiliar face affords a sense that they are not. 

Study 2 has participants to engage in two main tasks. 

First, participants envisage ways their face might look, and provide desirability ratings for these possibilities (Face Desirability Ratings). In particular, they imagine four distinct ways their face might look, and thereafter to indicate how much they ideally want their face to look like this. These four ways orthogonalize levels of attractiveness and familiarity. In the Absolute Condition, these four ways are: (a) Entirely Familiar & Amazingly Attractive; (b) Entirely Familiar & Hideously Unattractive; (c) Altogether Unfamiliar & Amazingly Attractive; and (d) Altogether Unfamiliar & Hideously Unattractive. In the Relative Condition, these four ways are: (a*) Entirely Familiar & Amazingly Attractive; (e) Entirely Familiar & As Attractive As It Is Now; (c*) Altogether Unfamiliar & Amazingly Attractive; and (f) Altogether Unfamiliar & As Attractive As it Is Now. (*=identical)

Second, participants envisage ways their face might look, and estimate the psychological effects of these possibilities being true (Face Effect Ratings). In particular, they imagine four distinct ways their face might look, and thereafter to indicate, via three separate ratings, how they would feel about their ability to "X" their world and life, where "X" is, respectively, "predict", "control", and"make sense of". The four distinct ways correspond to those for the desirability ratings, in the Absolute Condition and the Relative Condition. 

The purpose of having two versions, with different ranges for attractiveness, is take account of the fact that the logical zero-point of facial self-enhancement (Hideously Unattractive) may not be psychologically relevant zero-point, which is liable to be shifted in the direction of the status quo point (As Attractive As It Is Now), but whose exactly location is difficult to determine. However, the psychologically relevant zero-point is likely to lie somewhere in the interval between the logical zero-point and status quo point, such that the results of both versions of the study, pertaining to the interval extremes, will enable stronger conclusions to be drawn and more informed estimates of relative self-motive strength to be made. A similar distinction in other studies in the series.

In addition, participants are asked to indicate, at the beginning of the study, the extent to which they perceive their face to be attractive and familiar, and the extent to which they desire for their face to be attractive and familiar. These perceptions and desires can themselves serve as straightforward indications of how people think they stand in terms of these identity-relevant facial characteristics, and how much they want to facially self-enhance and self-verify in both an absolute sense and a relative sense. In addition, these perceptions and desires are liable to moderate the magnitude of the other findings.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 0 (H0)--so dubbed as it regarded as near self-evident--is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity.

Hypothesis 1 (H1) is that people will strive to verify their facial identity.

Hypothesis 2 (H2) is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity more than they strive to verify it.

These three hypotheses yield several predictions.

FIRST: As regards the extent to which participants' initial self-reported desire for their face to be attractive and familiar, we predict that they will want it to be more attractive than not (H0), and more familiar than not (H1), but also to want the former more than they want the latter (H2).

(Moderation: We predict that this will also be the case even when perceptions of facial attractiveness and familiarity are controlled for. In this regard, we do not predict any definite simple correlation between the perception of one's facial attractiveness and the desire to be facially attractive: although a deficiency of facial attractiveness might amplify desire for its improvement, it might also promote a downgrading of facial attractiveness, leading to a "draw". As for the correlation between facial familiarity and desire for facial familiarity, a lack of variation in the former case is liable to constrain correlations to the point of uninformativeness.)

(Ancillary: We predict that perceptions of attractiveness will be above the midpoint of the scale*, and, fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will also be above the midpoint of the scale. We also predict, again fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will be higher than perceptions of attractiveness. By default, most faces are surely nearly maximal in familiarity; but the motive to self-enhance is unlikely to be strong enough to convince nearly everyone that they are nearly maximal in attractiveness.)

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it reflects actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.

-------

Next, for both Face Desirability Ratings and Face Effect Ratings--and in both the Absolute Version and the Relative Version of the study--we make predictions (i) within each of the four conditions, and (ii) between those four conditions, taking the form of simple or competitive self-enhancing effects (involving attractiveness) and self-verifying effects (involving familiarity).

SECOND: Face Desirability Ratings

--Between-condition predictions

In terms of Face Desirability Ratings, we predict: 

An overall effect of attractiveness (H0), such that faces that are Amazingly Attractive are more desired than faces that are Hideously Unattractive (Absolute Version) or As They Are Now (Relative Version).

An overall effect of familiarity (H1), such that faces that are Entirely Familiar are more desired than faces that are Altogether Unfamiliar (Absolute & Relative Versions).

The above overall effect of attractiveness will exceed the above overall effect of familiarity (H2)

We also predict that, at each of the two levels of familiarity, there will be effect of attractiveness (H0), and that at each of the two levels of attractiveness, there will be an effect of familiarity (H1). Specifically, we predict that, for the conditions labelled above, in the  Absolute Version & Relative Version alike, the following differences will obtain:

H0: (a) > (b), (c) > (d); (a) > (e), (c) > (f)
H1: (a) > (c), (b) > (d); (e) > (f)

We also predict that, in conditions pitting attractiveness against familiarity, the former will prevail, in the Absolute Version & Relative Version alike:

H2: (c) > (b) and (c) > (e)

(Ancillary: We predict a further interactive effect, which is independent of our main hypotheses. It is that the effect of attractiveness will be stronger for familiar faces [or equivalently that the effect of familiarity will be stronger for attractive faces]. We make this prediction because, in addition to familiarity and attractiveness being desiderata in themselves, having a familiar face is liable to increase the self-relevance of having an attractive or unattractive face, and having an unfamiliar face is liable to decrease the self-relevance of having it, because one is rendered, respectively, more or less recognizable as oneself.)

--Within-condition predictions:

We predict that participants WILL generally desire the following facial outcomes, more than they do not desire them:

(a) Entirely Familiar & Amazingly Attractive (consistent with H0 and H1)
(e) Entirely Familiar & As Attractive As It Is Now (consistent with H0 and H1) *

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it depends on actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.

In addition, we predict that participants will generally NOT desire the following facial outcomes, more than they do desire them

(b) Entirely Familiar & Hideously Unattractive (supportive of H0 and H2)
(c) Altogether Unfamiliar & Amazingly Attractive (supportive of H1, and perhaps undermining of H2)

(d) Altogether Unfamiliar & Hideously Unattractive  (consistent with H0 and H1)
(f) Altogether Unfamiliar & As Attractive As it Is Now  (consistent with H0 and perhaps undermining of H2)

(Moderation 1: We predict that any advantage for self-enhancing strivings above will be more apparent in the Absolute condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is wider, than in the Relative condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is smaller. If H2 is falsified, then it is more likely to be falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition, or to be more strongly falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition.)

(Moderation 2: We predict that that the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings, in the direction of the former, will be positively related to participant's self-reported desires for their face to be attractive, and negatively related to their self-reported desires for their face to be familiar.)

(Moderation 3: We predict that self-enhancing strivings will be stronger (i) in women and (ii) in younger people, with such factors possibly combining synergistically. This is because, for evolutionary and lifespan reasons respectively, facial attractiveness has greater normative value for women and younger people. )

THIRD: Face Effect Ratings

In general, our predictions for Face Effect Ratings generally parallel for Face Desirability Ratings. To save space, they will not be reiterated.

Note, however, two important points.

First, there are three Face Effect Ratings for each predicted effect. These ratings are liable to be highly internally consistent, and a composite index thereof--referred to as "tractability", the degree to which people feel they are able to get a "handle" (i.e., gain "traction") on their life and world, by feeling it to be predictable, controllable, and coherent--will be derived. The three ratings will also be analyzed separately, but the same predictions are made in respect of all of them, and no predictions are made about differences in relative magnitude.

Second, the self-verification perspective holds that verification strivings are ultimately in the service of augmenting or maintain a sense of tractability. However, the possibility also arises, for several reasons, that self-enhancement strivings might do the same (e.g., the illusion of control is touted as one of the main examples of self-enhancement bias). However, the hypothesis that self-enhancement strivings, when satisfied, augment feelings of tractability even more than self-verification strivings, when satisfied, is perhaps surprising, given the existing view that the motives to self-enhance and self-verify compete, and that the latter sometimes dominate the former precisely in order to shore up feelings of tractability.

registration_responses.q14:
We expect to end up with a sample of about 400 usable participants, after excluding problematic cases.

This would entail about 200 usable participants per condition.

As the main analyses are within-participants, such numbers offer ample statistical power to make critical comparisons.

The between-participants comparisons (200 vs 200) offer less, but still ample, statistical power.

In particular, for a modest effect size of d = .3 (which we think many of our effects are liable to markedly exceed), we would be able to detect at a p< .01 level of significance (which use use to control our multiple comparisons) a within-group difference with N = 200 with a power probability of .9486 (rising to .9997 for a subset of analyses with N = 400).

In addition, for a modest effect size of d = .3, we would be able to detect at a p< .01 level of significance (which use use to control our multiple comparisons) a between-group difference with N = 400 with a power probability of .9513.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Note that the study has an observational and experimental elements.

Initial inquiries as to participants' perception of their facial attractiveness and familiarity, and their desire for facial attractiveness and familiarity, being analyzed in themselves, reflect a cross-sectional or observational design.

Otherwise, the study features an experimental design, sometimes in which the variables above features as predictors or covariates.

Overall, the experimental design of the study is mixed. The key comparisons are manipulated within-group. As mentioned earlier, these four conditions orthogonally cross attractiveness, at higher or lower levels, with familiarity, at higher or lower levels. Analyses are conducted on two sets of measures (which are not themselves compared): Face Desirability Ratings and Face Effect Ratings. These four within-groups conditions are, in each case, presented in randomized order. The version of the study administered serves as the between-group variable. In the Absolute Version of the study, the relevant attractiveness extremes are Hideously Unattractive and Amazingly Attractive; in the Relative Version of the study, the attractiveness extremes are As Attractive As You Are Now and Amazingly Attractive. In both the Absolute Version and the Relative version, the two familiarity extremes are Altogether Unfamiliar and Entirely Familiar.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be crowdsourced online using Amazon's Mechanical Turk platform in conjunction with TurkPrime. In recompense for a small fee ($.40), participants will be directed to the University of Southampton's local online research software iSurvey. There, they will click on a link for the study, read an information sheet, indicate their consent, complete one of several previously described versions of the study, read the debriefing, and receive the Completion Code they required to access payment on the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform. We will limit participants to those above the age of 18, and from the English-speaking Western countries of the USA, Canada, the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, Australia, and New Zealand. On the platform, participants will be required to have a hit approval rate of greater than 90%, and to have completed between 50 and 500,000 previous hits. In addition, participants will be excluded from completed any other study that is part of the Project, will be excluded if they have completed any other such study (e.g., if studies are run simultaneously). Recruitment of the 450 participants is expected to be brisk (within a week). Any participants showing signs of unearnest participation (e.g., taking part multiple times, providing nonsensical responses, not reporting the completion code) will be flagged for exclusion, flagged as problematic participants on MTurk, and possibly have their payment blocked.
