registration_responses.q18.question: There are three Face Effect Ratings for each predicted effect. These ratings are liable to be highly internally consistent, and a composite index thereof--referred to as "tractability", the degree to which people feel they are able to get a "handle" (i.e., gain "traction") on their life and world, by feeling it to be predictable, controllable, and coherent--will be derived. The three ratings will also be analyzed separately, but the same predictions are made in respect of all of them, and no predictions are made about differences in relative magnitude.
registration_responses.q19.question:
COPY-PASTED FROM EARLIER

[....
Hypothesis 0 (H0)--so dubbed as it regarded as near self-evident--is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity.

Hypothesis 1 (H1) is that people will strive to verify their facial identity. 

Hypothesis 2 (H2) is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity more than they strive to verify it.

These three hypotheses yield several predictions.

FIRST: as regards the extent to which participants self-reported desire for their face to be attractive and familiar, we predict that they will want it to be more attractive than not (H1), and more familiar than not (H2), but also to want the former more than they want the latter (H3).
...]
================================================
Here, two one-sample t-tests from the scale midpoint, and a within-group t-test, will be applied.
The analyses will be conducted collapsing across the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions, which here do not apply.
================================================


[....
(Moderation: We predict that this will also be the case even when perceptions of facial attractiveness and familiarity are controlled for. In this regard, we do not predict any definite simple correlation between the perception of one's facial attractiveness and the desire to be facially attractive: although a deficiency of facial attractiveness might amplify desire for its, it might also promote a downgrading of facial attractiveness, leading to a "draw". As for the correlation between facial familiarity and desire for facial familiarity, a lack of variation in the former case is liable to constrain correlations to the point of uninformativeness.)
...]
================================================
We will look at all correlations using Pearson 's (more sensitive) and Spearman's (more robust) coefficients. We will compute the four correlations involving these variables, not predicting any to be significant. We will also show that the differences from the scale midpoint in desire to be facially attractive remain significant for participants both above and below the scale midpoint, and/or median in perceptions of facial attractiveness.
The analyses will be conducted collapsing across the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions, which here do not apply.
================================================

[...(Ancillary: We predict that perceptions of attractiveness will be above the midpoint of the scale*, and, fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will also be above the midpoint of the scale. We also predict, again fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will be higher than perceptions of attractiveness. By default, most faces are surely nearly maximal in familiarity; but the motive to self-enhance is unlikely to be strong enough to convince nearly everyone that they are nearly maximal in attractiveness.)

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it reflects actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.
...]

================================================
Here, one-sample t-tests from the scale midpoint, and a within-group t-test, will again applied.
The analyses will be conducted collapsing across the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions, which here do not apply.
================================================



-------

Next, for both Face Desirability Ratings and Face Effect Ratings--and in both the Absolute Version and the Relative Version of the study--we make predictions (i) within each of the four conditions, and (ii) between those four conditions, taking the form of simple or competitive self-enhancing effects (involving attractiveness) and self-verifying effects (involving familiarity).

SECOND: Face Desirability Ratings

--Between-condition predictions

[...
In terms of Face Desirability Ratings, we predict: 

An overall effect of attractiveness (H0), such that faces that are Amazingly Attractive are more desired than faces that are Hideously Unattractive (Absolute Version) or As They Are Now (Relative Version).

An overall effect of familiarity (H1), such that faces that are Entirely Familiar are more desired than faces that are Altogether Unfamiliar (Absolute & Relative Versions).

The above overall effect of attractiveness will exceed the above overall effect of familiarity (H2)
...]
================================================
Here, a 2 x 2 within-group ANOVA will be conducted, 
and the main effects tested and compared.
The analyses will be conducted separately for the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions.
================================================

[...
We also predict that, at each of the two levels of familiarity, there will be effect of attractiveness (H0), and that at each of the two levels of attractiveness, there will be an effect of familiarity (H1). Specifically, we predict that, for the conditions labelled above, in the  Absolute Version & Relative Version alike, the following differences will obtain:

H0: (a) > (b), (c) > (d); (a) > (e), (c) > (f)
H1: (a) > (c), (b) > (d); (e) > (f)

We also predict that, in conditions pitting attractiveness against familiarity, the former will prevail, in the Absolute Version & Relative Version alike:

H2: (c) > (b) and (c) > (e)
...]

================================================
Here, follow-up simple effects,and planned comparisons, 
will be conducted as within-group t-tests.
The analyses will be conducted separately for the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions.
================================================

[...
(Ancillary: We predict a further interactive effect, which is independent of our main hypotheses. It is that the effect of attractiveness will be stronger for familiar faces [or equivalently that the effect of familiarity will be stronger for attractive faces]. We make this prediction because, in addition to familiarity and attractiveness being desiderata in themselves, having a familiar face is liable to increase the self-relevance of having an attractive or unattractive face, and having an unfamiliar face is liable to decrease the self-relevance of having it, because one is rendered, respectively, more or less recognizable as oneself.)
...]

================================================
Here, a 2 x 2 within-group ANOVA will be conducted, 
and the interaction effect tested.
The analyses will be conducted separately for the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions.
================================================

--Within-condition predictions:

[...
We predict that participants WILL generally desire the following facial outcomes, more than they do not desire them:

(a) Entirely Familiar & Amazingly Attractive (consistent with H0 and H1)
(e) Entirely Familiar & As Attractive As It Is Now (consistent with H0 and H1) *

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it depends on actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.

In addition, we predict that participants will generally NOT desire the following facial outcomes, more than they do desire them

(b) Entirely Familiar & Hideously Unattractive (supportive of H0 and H2)
(c) Altogether Unfamiliar & Amazingly Attractive (supportive of H1, and perhaps undermining of H2)

(d) Altogether Unfamiliar & Hideously Unattractive  (consistent with H0 and H1)
(f) Altogether Unfamiliar & As Attractive As it Is Now  (consistent with H0 and perhaps undermining of H2)
...]

================================================
Here, one-sample t-tests from the scale midpoint will again be applied.
The analyses will be conducted separately for the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions.
================================================

[...
(Moderation 1: We predict that any advantage for self-enhancing strivings above will be more apparent in the Absolute condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is wider, than in the Relative condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is smaller. If H2 is falsified, then it is more likely to be falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition, or to be more strongly falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition.)
...]

================================================
Here, if the analyses above were a one-sample t-test, a between-group t-test will be conducted.
Here, if the analyses above were a within-group t-test, a mixed 2 x 2 ANOVA will be conducted.
Here, if the analyses above were a mixed 2 x 2 ANOVA will be conducted, a mixed 2 x 2 x 2 ANOVA will be conducted.
================================================

[...
(Moderation 2: We predict that that the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings, in the direction of the former, will be positively related to participant's self-reported desires for their face to be attractive, and negatively related to their self-reported desires for their face to be familiar.)
...]

================================================
Here, where the evidence for the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings was a single score, we will linearly regress those scores on the desire for attractiveness and desire for familiarity; where it was a within-group difference we will do the same, after first computing the relevant within-group difference score; and where it was a higher-order within-group difference score (i.e., for the 2 x 2 interaction), we will do the same after first computing the relevant difference-between-differences score. 
================================================

[...
(Moderation 3: We predict that self-enhancing strivings will be stronger (i) in women and (ii) in younger people, with such factors possibly combining synergistically. This is because, for evolutionary and lifespan reasons respectively, facial attractiveness has greater normative value for women and younger people. )
...]
================================================
For gender, where the key analysis was previous a one-sample t-test, a between-group t-test will be conducted; and where it was a within-group t-test, a mixed 2 x 2 ANOVA will be conducted; and where it was a higher-order within-group difference score (i.e., for the 2 x 2 interaction), a mixed 2 x 2 x 2 ANOVA will be conducted. For age, where the evidence for the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings was a single score, we will linearly regress those scores on age; where it was a within-subject difference, we will do the same, after first computing the relevant within-group difference score; and where it was a higher-order within-group difference score (i.e., for the 2 x 2 interaction), we will do the same after first computing the relevant difference-between-differences score. 
================================================

THIRD: Face Effect Ratings

We will replicate all the above analyses for the Tractability composite, and all the tractability indices separately.

attributes.title: The Self-Enhancement versus Self-Verification of Facial Identity
attributes.description: Participants imagine possible ways their face might be, in terms of being more or less attractive and familiar. Their reactions afford evidence of the operation and strength of the motives to self-enhance and self-verify.

q1.value: Facial Self-Motives 1: Elective Hypothetical Face Modifications, Thereby Pitting Self-Enhancing Striving for Facial Attractiveness Against Self-Verifying Striving for Facial Familiarity

q3.value:
This is Study 1 in a series of studies. Their overall purpose is to test whether people are motivated to verify as well as to enhance their facial identity, and to what extent they are motivated to do one versus the other. The motive to self-enhance is presumed to be captured by striving for facial attractiveness: having an attractive face affords a positive evaluation whereas having an unattractive face affords a negative evaluation. The motive to self-verify is presumed to be captured by striving for facial familiarity: having a familiar face affords a sense that one's life and world are predictable, controllable,and coherent whereas having an unfamiliar face affords a sense that they are not.

Study 1 has participants indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face if they were able to, in the following situations: 

(a) its attractiveness is fixed (at 100%) but its familiarity can be modified; 
(b) its familiarity is fixed (at 100%) but its attractiveness can be modified; or 
(c) its attractiveness can be modified, but only such that its familiarity varies inversely with any modifications.

In addition, the study comes in two versions. In both versions, participants can modify the familiarity of their face between being Altogether Unfamiliar (0%) and Entirely Familiar (100%): that is the relevant range. However, whereas in the Absolute version, participants can modify the attractiveness of their face between being Hideously Unattractive (0%) and Amazingly Attractive (100%), in the Relative version, participants can modify the attractiveness of their face between being As It Is Now (0% = status quo) and being Amazingly Attractive (100% *more* attractive). The purpose of having two versions, with different ranges for attractiveness, is take account of the fact that the logical zero-point of facial self-enhancement (Hideously Unattractive) may not be psychologically relevant zero-point, which is liable to be shifted in the direction of the status quo point (As It Is Now), but whose exactly location is difficult to determine. However, the psychologically relevant zero-point is likely to lie somewhere in the interval between the logical zero-point and status quo point, such that the results of both versions of the study, pertaining to the interval extremes, will enable stronger conclusions to be drawn and more informed estimates of relative self-motive strength to be made. 

The Absolute Version of the study features only scenarios (b) and (c) above.
The Relative Version of the study features scenarios (a), (b), and (c).

In addition, participants are asked to indicate, at the beginning of the study, the extent to which they perceive their face to be attractive and familiar, and the extent to which they desire for their face to be attractive and familiar. These perceptions and desires can themselves serve as straightforward indications of how people think they stand in terms of these identity-relevant facial characteristics, and how much they want to facially self-enhance and self-verify in both an absolute sense and a relative sense. In addition, these perceptions and desires are liable to moderate the magnitude of the other findings.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 0 (H0)--so dubbed as it regarded as near self-evident--is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity.

Hypothesis 1 (H1) is that people will strive to verify their facial identity. 

Hypothesis 2 (H2) is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity more than they strive to verify it.

These three hypotheses yield several predictions.

FIRST: As regards the extent to which participants' initial self-reported desire for their face to be attractive and familiar, we predict that they will want it to be more attractive than not (H0), and more familiar than not (H1), but also to want the former more than they want the latter (H2).

(Moderation: We predict that this will also be the case even when perceptions of facial attractiveness and familiarity are controlled for. In this regard, we do not predict any definite simple correlation between the perception of one's facial attractiveness and the desire to be facially attractive: although a deficiency of facial attractiveness might amplify desire for its improvement, it might also promote a downgrading of facial attractiveness, leading to a "draw". As for the correlation between facial familiarity and desire for facial familiarity, a lack of variation in the former case is liable to constrain correlations to the point of uninformativeness.)

(Ancillary: We predict that perceptions of attractiveness will be above the midpoint of the scale*, and, fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will also be above the midpoint of the scale. We also predict, again fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will be higher than perceptions of attractiveness. By default, most faces are surely nearly maximal in familiarity; but the motive to self-enhance is unlikely to be strong enough to convince nearly everyone that they are nearly maximal in attractiveness.)

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it reflects actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.


SECOND: in the Absolute Version of the study, we predict that, in Condition (b), participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive, with familiarity held constant at 100% (H0); and in Condition (a), that participants will move their face to be closer to being Entirely Familiar than it is to being Altogether Unfamiliar, with attractiveness being held constant at 100% (H1). In Condition (c), we also predict that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive (H0). This will demonstrate that, even when antagonized by self-verification strivings (reflected in the trade-off between making their face less familiar as they make it more attractive) self-enhancement strivings persist. At the same time, we predict that facial attractiveness augmentation will be curtailed in Condition (c) relative to Condition (b), thereby demonstrating the operation of self-verification verification strivings over and above self-enhancement strivings. Still, in predicting that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive, we also predict that self-enhancement strivings will dominate self-verification strivings (H2). Finally, we predict that participants will, in Condition (b), move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive than they will, in Condition (a), move their face to be closer to being Entirely Familiar than it is to being Altogether Unfamiliar. This again would also reflect self-enhancement strivings dominating self-verification strivings (H2). 

THIRD: in the Relative Version of the study, we predict that, in Condition (b), participants will make their face more attractive than As It Is Now (H0). We further predict that they will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being As It Is Now (H0). In Condition (c), we also predict that participants will make their face more attractive than it is As It Is Now (H0). This will demonstrate that, even when antagonized by self-verification strivings (reflected in the trade-off between making their face less familiar as they make it more attractive) self-enhancement strivings persist. At the same time, we predict that facial attractiveness augmentation will be curtailed in Condition (c) relative to Condition (b), thereby demonstrating the operation of self-verification verification strivings over and above self-enhancement strivings. Still, we still predict that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being As It Is Now, consistent with self-enhancement strivings dominating self-verification strivings.

(Moderation 1: We predict that any advantage for self-enhancing strivings above will be more apparent in the Absolute condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is wider, than in the Relative condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is smaller. If H2 is falsified, then it is more likely to be falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition, or to be more strongly falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition.)

(Moderation 2: We predict that that the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings, in the direction of the former, will be positively related to participant's self-reported desires for their face to be attractive, and negatively related to their self-reported desires for their face to be familiar.)

(Moderation 3: We predict that self-enhancing strivings will be stronger (i) in women and (ii) in younger people, with such factors possibly combining synergistically. This is because, for evolutionary and lifespan reasons respectively, facial attractiveness has greater normative value for women and younger people. )

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value:
As regards the allocation to the Absolute Version and Relative Version of the study, these being between-subject, participants will NOT know the treatment group to which they have been assigned. Likewise, researcher will not know which participants have been assigned to which treatment group.

However, as regards allocation to the conditions (a), (b), and (c), these being within-participants, participants WILL know the treatment group to which they have been assigned. Likewise, the researche will know this.

However, the study being conducted online, with crowdsourced participants managed by a third party (Amazon's Mechanical Turk), the researcher can have no influence over participants as they are allocated to conditions.

question.value:
Note that the study has an observational and experimental elements.

Initial inquiries as to participants' perception of their facial attractiveness and familiarity, and their desire for facial attractiveness and familiarity, being analyzed in themselves, reflect a cross-sectional or observational design.

Otherwise, the study features an experimental design, sometimes in which the variables above features as predictors or covariates.

Overall, the experimental design of the study is mixed, but not completely balanced. The key comparisons are manipulated within-group. As mentioned earlier, these conditions are that (a) facial familiarity can be modified with facial attractiveness fixed, (b) facial attractiveness can be modified with facial familiarity fixed, and (c) facial attractiveness can be modified with facial familiarity varying inversely with it.The version of the study administered serves as the between-group variable. In addition, whereas an Absolute Version of the study features all three conditions, and facial attractiveness can be modified across the full range, from Hideously Unattractive to Amazingly Attractive, the Relative Version of the study features only Condition (b) and (c), and facial attractiveness can be modified only across the partial range, from As I Am Now to Amazingly Attractive. The within-group conditions are not randomized but presented in quasi-fixed order, the reason being that Condition (c) is harder to understand, and better presented after another condition, which it builds on. The preceding condition is always just Condition (b) in the Relative Version, but is Condition (a) and Condition (b) Absolute Version, whose order is duly systematically counterbalanced in the order that participants complete the study online, which approximates complete randomization and ensures equivalent sample size. Assignment of participants to the Relative Version or the Absolute Version is systematically counterbalanced in the same way.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be crowdsourced online using Amazon's Mechanical Turk platform in conjunction with TurkPrime. In recompense for a small fee ($.25), participants will be directed to the University of Southampton's local online research software iSurvey. There, they will click on a link for the study, read an information sheet, indicate their consent, complete one of several previously described versions of the study, read the debriefing, and receive the Completion Code they required to access payment on the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform. We will limit participants to those above the age of 18, and from the English-speaking Western countries of the USA, Canada, the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, Australia, and New Zealand. On the platform, participants will be required to have a hit approval rate of greater than 90%, and to have completed between 50 and 500,000 previous hits. In addition, participants will be excluded from completed any other study that is part of the Project, will be excluded if they have completed any other such study (e.g., if studies are run simultaneously). Recruitment of the 450 participants is expected to be brisk (within a week). Any participants showing signs of unearnest participation (e.g., taking part multiple times, providing nonsensical responses, not reporting the completion code) will be flagged for exclusion, flagged as problematic participants on MTurk, and possibly have their payment blocked.

q13.value:
We plan to collect 450 participants. 

Of these, half will be allocated to the Absolute Version, and half to the Relative Version.

q14.value:
We expect to end up with a sample of about 400 usable participants, after excluding problematic cases.

This would entail about 200 usable participants per condition.

As the main analyses are within-participants, such numbers offer ample statistical power to make critical comparisons.

The between-participants comparisons (200 vs 200) offer less, but still ample, statistical power.

In particular, for a modest effect size of d = .3 (which we think many of our effects are liable to markedly exceed), we would be able to detect at a p< .01 level of significance (which use use to control our multiple comparisons) a within-group difference with N = 200 with a power probability of .9486 (rising to .9997 for a subset of analyses with N = 400).

In addition, for a modest effect size of d = .3, we would be able to detect at a p< .01 level of significance (which use use to control our multiple comparisons) a between-group difference with N = 400 with a power probability of .9513.

q15.value: Not relevant. We will stop after 450 participants.

question.value:
------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (a)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face UNFAMILIAR or FAMILIAR.
If so, how UNFAMILIAR or FAMILIAR would you make your face, on a 0% to 100% scale?
At one extreme, you could MAKE your face AS UNFAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 0%).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100%).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
Also suppose that, no matter how familiar you make your face, it would still look AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (100%).
That is, your face would still be EXTREMELY PLEASANT TO LOOK AT, regardless.
So: how UNFAMILIAR or FAMILIAR would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

0% familiar / 100% attractive
5% familiar / 100% attractive
...
95% familiar / 100% attractive
100% familiar / 100% attractive

------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (b)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE.
If so, how UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE would you make your face, on a 0% to 100% scale?
At one extreme, you could MAKE your face AS UNATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 0%).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100%).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
Also suppose that, no matter how attractive you make your face, it would still look AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (100%).
That is, your face would still look JUST LIKE YOU, regardless.
So: how UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

0% attractive / 100% familiar
5% attractive / 100% familiar
...
95% attractive / 100% familiar
100% attractive / 100% familiar

------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (c)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE.
If so, how UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE would you make your face, on a 0% to 100% scale?
At one extreme, you could MAKE your face AS UNATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 0%).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100%).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
However, there is complication...
The MORE ATTRACTIVE you make yourself, the LESS FAMILIAR you will look.
The LESS ATTRACTIVE you make yourself, the MORE FAMILIAR you will look.
So, if you MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE, it will then look AS UNFAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (0% LIKE YOU).
Yet, if you MAKE your face AS UNATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE, it will then look AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (100% LIKE YOU).
In other words, there is a perfectly balanced TRADE OFF between your face looking familiar, and your face looking attractive.
So: how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%), and how MUCH less familiar will you make your face (100% to 0%), at the same time?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

0% attractive / 100% familiar
5% attractive / 95% familiar
...
95% attractive / 5% familiar
100% attractive / 0% familiar

------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (b)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face MORE ATTRACTIVE.
If so, how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
At one extreme, you could LEAVE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS IT IS NOW (that is, make it 0% more attractive).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100% more attractive).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
Also suppose that, no matter how much more attractive you make your face, it would still look AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (100%).
That is, your face would still look JUST LIKE YOU, regardless.
So: how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

As attractive as you are now / 100% familiar
5% more attractive than you are now / 100% familiar
...
95% more attractive than you are now / 100% familiar
100% more attractive than you are now / 100% familiar
------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (c)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face MORE ATTRACTIVE.
If so, how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
At one extreme, you could LEAVE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS IT IS NOW (that is, make it 0% more attractive).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100% more attractive).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
However, there is complication...
The MORE ATTRACTIVE you make yourself, the LESS FAMILIAR you will then look.
The LESS ATTRACTIVE you make yourself, the MORE FAMILIAR you will still look.
So, if you MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE, it will then look AS UNFAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (0% LIKE YOU).
But, if you LEAVE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS IT IS NOW, it will still look AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (100% LIKE YOU).
In other words, there is a perfectly balanced TRADE OFF between your face looking familiar, and your face looking more attractive.
So: how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%), and how MUCH less familiar will you make your face (100% to 0%), at the same time?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

As attractive as you are now / 100% familiar
5% more attractive than you are now / 95% familiar
...
95% more attractive than you are now / 5% familiar
100% more attractive than you are now / 0% familiar

q20.value: We do not plan on transforming any variables. With the exception of the perception of face familiarity, whose external relations may be too homogeneous to merit analysis, we expect all other continuous variables to exhibit a unimodal distribution that is not intolerably skewed or otherwise odd. If one or more variables turn out to be intolerably distributed, we may apply a standard recommended distributional transformation, but we will analyze the data both ways and report the results.

q21.value:
We will only employ two-tailed tests.

Generally, we will employ null hypothesis significance testing, with p < .01 as a statistical significance cutoff, and will report findings between p = .01 and p = .05 as merely suggestive.

As our critical comparisons are focal and theoretically predicted, and relatively few in number, we will not make adjustments for multiple comparisons.

q22.value:
To help ensure its quality, we will screen our crowdsourced data as follows: 

Duplicate check: Remove all cases where the respondent is liable to have participated more than once (now done automatically by the MTurk platform preventing multiple responses from the same IP address)

Speed check: Remove all cases where respondents completed the tasks in less than 1/3 or 1/2 of the median completion time (for short surveys, the former is sometimes better)
Completion check: Remove all cases where respondents have completed less than 90% or 95% of the key questions  (for short surveys, the former is sometimes better)

Age check: Remove all participants reporting being under 18 years of age (despite this being a criterion specified by the platform)

Fluency check: Remove all participants reporting that their English is less than the midpoint on the 5 point scale (i.e., include only Perfect, Very Good, Okay; exclude Bad, or Very Bad).

Conscientiousness check: Remove all cases whether participants do not answer validation questions correctly (either or both of the following: a set of six obviously true or false questions; an instruction to write a grammatically correct but absurd short sentence).

We will inspect our data for univariate and bivariate outliers, and analyze both including and excluding them, reporting both (perhaps in a supplement).

Univariate outliers we define as those values lying outside the Tukey (1977) fence in a Box-and- Whiskers graph: below Q1 – 1.5×IQR or above Q3 + 1.5×IQR.

Bivariate outliers can be defined as lying outside the Rousseeuw, Ruts, & Tukey (2002) fence in the Bagplot, obtained by inflating B relative to the depth median T by a factor of 3.

q23.value: We will retain all cases where a participant, who has met all other criteria, completes 90% or 95% o of the analysis-pertinent items. Typically, the great majority crowdsourced participants meet this criterion. Hence, the number of missing data points in the final dataset is low, and does not unduly perturb the types of analyses we plan on conducting.

q24.value:
We asked participants to give one or more reasons for why they chose to make their face some % of attractive, familiar, or combination of both.

We will code these verbal report for evidence that they did so because it made their life and world feel more predictable, controllable, or coherent. Self-verification theory claims that these are the motivations that ultimately underlie the motive to self-verify. Hence, mention of such reasons may be hypothesized to be more prominent in conditions where levels familiarity may be varied (i.e., [a], [c]) than in the condition in which it is held constant (i.e., [b])

Note: we address this question using close-ended items in Study 2 in the series.

registration_responses.q1: Facial Self-Motives 1: Elective Hypothetical Face Modifications, Thereby Pitting Self-Enhancing Striving for Facial Attractiveness Against Self-Verifying Striving for Facial Familiarity
registration_responses.q3:
This is Study 1 in a series of studies. Their overall purpose is to test whether people are motivated to verify as well as to enhance their facial identity, and to what extent they are motivated to do one versus the other. The motive to self-enhance is presumed to be captured by striving for facial attractiveness: having an attractive face affords a positive evaluation whereas having an unattractive face affords a negative evaluation. The motive to self-verify is presumed to be captured by striving for facial familiarity: having a familiar face affords a sense that one's life and world are predictable, controllable,and coherent whereas having an unfamiliar face affords a sense that they are not.

Study 1 has participants indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face if they were able to, in the following situations: 

(a) its attractiveness is fixed (at 100%) but its familiarity can be modified; 
(b) its familiarity is fixed (at 100%) but its attractiveness can be modified; or 
(c) its attractiveness can be modified, but only such that its familiarity varies inversely with any modifications.

In addition, the study comes in two versions. In both versions, participants can modify the familiarity of their face between being Altogether Unfamiliar (0%) and Entirely Familiar (100%): that is the relevant range. However, whereas in the Absolute version, participants can modify the attractiveness of their face between being Hideously Unattractive (0%) and Amazingly Attractive (100%), in the Relative version, participants can modify the attractiveness of their face between being As It Is Now (0% = status quo) and being Amazingly Attractive (100% *more* attractive). The purpose of having two versions, with different ranges for attractiveness, is take account of the fact that the logical zero-point of facial self-enhancement (Hideously Unattractive) may not be psychologically relevant zero-point, which is liable to be shifted in the direction of the status quo point (As It Is Now), but whose exactly location is difficult to determine. However, the psychologically relevant zero-point is likely to lie somewhere in the interval between the logical zero-point and status quo point, such that the results of both versions of the study, pertaining to the interval extremes, will enable stronger conclusions to be drawn and more informed estimates of relative self-motive strength to be made. 

The Absolute Version of the study features only scenarios (b) and (c) above.
The Relative Version of the study features scenarios (a), (b), and (c).

In addition, participants are asked to indicate, at the beginning of the study, the extent to which they perceive their face to be attractive and familiar, and the extent to which they desire for their face to be attractive and familiar. These perceptions and desires can themselves serve as straightforward indications of how people think they stand in terms of these identity-relevant facial characteristics, and how much they want to facially self-enhance and self-verify in both an absolute sense and a relative sense. In addition, these perceptions and desires are liable to moderate the magnitude of the other findings.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 0 (H0)--so dubbed as it regarded as near self-evident--is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity.

Hypothesis 1 (H1) is that people will strive to verify their facial identity. 

Hypothesis 2 (H2) is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity more than they strive to verify it.

These three hypotheses yield several predictions.

FIRST: As regards the extent to which participants' initial self-reported desire for their face to be attractive and familiar, we predict that they will want it to be more attractive than not (H0), and more familiar than not (H1), but also to want the former more than they want the latter (H2).

(Moderation: We predict that this will also be the case even when perceptions of facial attractiveness and familiarity are controlled for. In this regard, we do not predict any definite simple correlation between the perception of one's facial attractiveness and the desire to be facially attractive: although a deficiency of facial attractiveness might amplify desire for its improvement, it might also promote a downgrading of facial attractiveness, leading to a "draw". As for the correlation between facial familiarity and desire for facial familiarity, a lack of variation in the former case is liable to constrain correlations to the point of uninformativeness.)

(Ancillary: We predict that perceptions of attractiveness will be above the midpoint of the scale*, and, fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will also be above the midpoint of the scale. We also predict, again fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will be higher than perceptions of attractiveness. By default, most faces are surely nearly maximal in familiarity; but the motive to self-enhance is unlikely to be strong enough to convince nearly everyone that they are nearly maximal in attractiveness.)

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it reflects actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.


SECOND: in the Absolute Version of the study, we predict that, in Condition (b), participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive, with familiarity held constant at 100% (H0); and in Condition (a), that participants will move their face to be closer to being Entirely Familiar than it is to being Altogether Unfamiliar, with attractiveness being held constant at 100% (H1). In Condition (c), we also predict that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive (H0). This will demonstrate that, even when antagonized by self-verification strivings (reflected in the trade-off between making their face less familiar as they make it more attractive) self-enhancement strivings persist. At the same time, we predict that facial attractiveness augmentation will be curtailed in Condition (c) relative to Condition (b), thereby demonstrating the operation of self-verification verification strivings over and above self-enhancement strivings. Still, in predicting that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive, we also predict that self-enhancement strivings will dominate self-verification strivings (H2). Finally, we predict that participants will, in Condition (b), move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive than they will, in Condition (a), move their face to be closer to being Entirely Familiar than it is to being Altogether Unfamiliar. This again would also reflect self-enhancement strivings dominating self-verification strivings (H2). 

THIRD: in the Relative Version of the study, we predict that, in Condition (b), participants will make their face more attractive than As It Is Now (H0). We further predict that they will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being As It Is Now (H0). In Condition (c), we also predict that participants will make their face more attractive than it is As It Is Now (H0). This will demonstrate that, even when antagonized by self-verification strivings (reflected in the trade-off between making their face less familiar as they make it more attractive) self-enhancement strivings persist. At the same time, we predict that facial attractiveness augmentation will be curtailed in Condition (c) relative to Condition (b), thereby demonstrating the operation of self-verification verification strivings over and above self-enhancement strivings. Still, we still predict that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being As It Is Now, consistent with self-enhancement strivings dominating self-verification strivings.

(Moderation 1: We predict that any advantage for self-enhancing strivings above will be more apparent in the Absolute condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is wider, than in the Relative condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is smaller. If H2 is falsified, then it is more likely to be falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition, or to be more strongly falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition.)

(Moderation 2: We predict that that the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings, in the direction of the former, will be positively related to participant's self-reported desires for their face to be attractive, and negatively related to their self-reported desires for their face to be familiar.)

(Moderation 3: We predict that self-enhancing strivings will be stronger (i) in women and (ii) in younger people, with such factors possibly combining synergistically. This is because, for evolutionary and lifespan reasons respectively, facial attractiveness has greater normative value for women and younger people. )
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q7:
As regards the allocation to the Absolute Version and Relative Version of the study, these being between-subject, participants will NOT know the treatment group to which they have been assigned. Likewise, researcher will not know which participants have been assigned to which treatment group.

However, as regards allocation to the conditions (a), (b), and (c), these being within-participants, participants WILL know the treatment group to which they have been assigned. Likewise, the researche will know this.

However, the study being conducted online, with crowdsourced participants managed by a third party (Amazon's Mechanical Turk), the researcher can have no influence over participants as they are allocated to conditions.

registration_responses.q13:
We plan to collect 450 participants. 

Of these, half will be allocated to the Absolute Version, and half to the Relative Version.
registration_responses.q14:
We expect to end up with a sample of about 400 usable participants, after excluding problematic cases.

This would entail about 200 usable participants per condition.

As the main analyses are within-participants, such numbers offer ample statistical power to make critical comparisons.

The between-participants comparisons (200 vs 200) offer less, but still ample, statistical power.

In particular, for a modest effect size of d = .3 (which we think many of our effects are liable to markedly exceed), we would be able to detect at a p< .01 level of significance (which use use to control our multiple comparisons) a within-group difference with N = 200 with a power probability of .9486 (rising to .9997 for a subset of analyses with N = 400).

In addition, for a modest effect size of d = .3, we would be able to detect at a p< .01 level of significance (which use use to control our multiple comparisons) a between-group difference with N = 400 with a power probability of .9513.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Note that the study has an observational and experimental elements.

Initial inquiries as to participants' perception of their facial attractiveness and familiarity, and their desire for facial attractiveness and familiarity, being analyzed in themselves, reflect a cross-sectional or observational design.

Otherwise, the study features an experimental design, sometimes in which the variables above features as predictors or covariates.

Overall, the experimental design of the study is mixed, but not completely balanced. The key comparisons are manipulated within-group. As mentioned earlier, these conditions are that (a) facial familiarity can be modified with facial attractiveness fixed, (b) facial attractiveness can be modified with facial familiarity fixed, and (c) facial attractiveness can be modified with facial familiarity varying inversely with it.The version of the study administered serves as the between-group variable. In addition, whereas an Absolute Version of the study features all three conditions, and facial attractiveness can be modified across the full range, from Hideously Unattractive to Amazingly Attractive, the Relative Version of the study features only Condition (b) and (c), and facial attractiveness can be modified only across the partial range, from As I Am Now to Amazingly Attractive. The within-group conditions are not randomized but presented in quasi-fixed order, the reason being that Condition (c) is harder to understand, and better presented after another condition, which it builds on. The preceding condition is always just Condition (b) in the Relative Version, but is Condition (a) and Condition (b) Absolute Version, whose order is duly systematically counterbalanced in the order that participants complete the study online, which approximates complete randomization and ensures equivalent sample size. Assignment of participants to the Relative Version or the Absolute Version is systematically counterbalanced in the same way.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be crowdsourced online using Amazon's Mechanical Turk platform in conjunction with TurkPrime. In recompense for a small fee ($.25), participants will be directed to the University of Southampton's local online research software iSurvey. There, they will click on a link for the study, read an information sheet, indicate their consent, complete one of several previously described versions of the study, read the debriefing, and receive the Completion Code they required to access payment on the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform. We will limit participants to those above the age of 18, and from the English-speaking Western countries of the USA, Canada, the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, Australia, and New Zealand. On the platform, participants will be required to have a hit approval rate of greater than 90%, and to have completed between 50 and 500,000 previous hits. In addition, participants will be excluded from completed any other study that is part of the Project, will be excluded if they have completed any other such study (e.g., if studies are run simultaneously). Recruitment of the 450 participants is expected to be brisk (within a week). Any participants showing signs of unearnest participation (e.g., taking part multiple times, providing nonsensical responses, not reporting the completion code) will be flagged for exclusion, flagged as problematic participants on MTurk, and possibly have their payment blocked.
registration_responses.q16.question:
------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (a)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face UNFAMILIAR or FAMILIAR.
If so, how UNFAMILIAR or FAMILIAR would you make your face, on a 0% to 100% scale?
At one extreme, you could MAKE your face AS UNFAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 0%).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100%).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
Also suppose that, no matter how familiar you make your face, it would still look AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (100%).
That is, your face would still be EXTREMELY PLEASANT TO LOOK AT, regardless.
So: how UNFAMILIAR or FAMILIAR would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

0% familiar / 100% attractive
5% familiar / 100% attractive
...
95% familiar / 100% attractive
100% familiar / 100% attractive

------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (b)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE.
If so, how UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE would you make your face, on a 0% to 100% scale?
At one extreme, you could MAKE your face AS UNATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 0%).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100%).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
Also suppose that, no matter how attractive you make your face, it would still look AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (100%).
That is, your face would still look JUST LIKE YOU, regardless.
So: how UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

0% attractive / 100% familiar
5% attractive / 100% familiar
...
95% attractive / 100% familiar
100% attractive / 100% familiar

------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (c)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE.
If so, how UNATTRACTIVE or ATTRACTIVE would you make your face, on a 0% to 100% scale?
At one extreme, you could MAKE your face AS UNATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 0%).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100%).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
However, there is complication...
The MORE ATTRACTIVE you make yourself, the LESS FAMILIAR you will look.
The LESS ATTRACTIVE you make yourself, the MORE FAMILIAR you will look.
So, if you MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE, it will then look AS UNFAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (0% LIKE YOU).
Yet, if you MAKE your face AS UNATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE, it will then look AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (100% LIKE YOU).
In other words, there is a perfectly balanced TRADE OFF between your face looking familiar, and your face looking attractive.
So: how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%), and how MUCH less familiar will you make your face (100% to 0%), at the same time?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

0% attractive / 100% familiar
5% attractive / 95% familiar
...
95% attractive / 5% familiar
100% attractive / 0% familiar

------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (b)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face MORE ATTRACTIVE.
If so, how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
At one extreme, you could LEAVE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS IT IS NOW (that is, make it 0% more attractive).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100% more attractive).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
Also suppose that, no matter how much more attractive you make your face, it would still look AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (100%).
That is, your face would still look JUST LIKE YOU, regardless.
So: how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

As attractive as you are now / 100% familiar
5% more attractive than you are now / 100% familiar
...
95% more attractive than you are now / 100% familiar
100% more attractive than you are now / 100% familiar
------------------
ABSOLUTE VERSION, Condition (c)

"
Suppose you had the option of MAKING your face MORE ATTRACTIVE.
If so, how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%)?
At one extreme, you could LEAVE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS IT IS NOW (that is, make it 0% more attractive).
At the other extreme, you could MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE (that is, make it 100% more attractive).
Or, anything IN BETWEEN.
However, there is complication...
The MORE ATTRACTIVE you make yourself, the LESS FAMILIAR you will then look.
The LESS ATTRACTIVE you make yourself, the MORE FAMILIAR you will still look.
So, if you MAKE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS POSSIBLE, it will then look AS UNFAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (0% LIKE YOU).
But, if you LEAVE your face AS ATTRACTIVE AS IT IS NOW, it will still look AS FAMILIAR AS POSSIBLE (100% LIKE YOU).
In other words, there is a perfectly balanced TRADE OFF between your face looking familiar, and your face looking more attractive.
So: how MUCH more attractive would you make your face (0% to 100%), and how MUCH less familiar will you make your face (100% to 0%), at the same time?
"

A graphic with colored lines representing continuously varying levels of attractiveness and familiarity will then illustrate the nature of the options. Participants will then click one of 21 options to indicate how they would hypothetically modify their face, ranging in 5% increments from...

As attractive as you are now / 100% familiar
5% more attractive than you are now / 95% familiar
...
95% more attractive than you are now / 5% familiar
100% more attractive than you are now / 0% familiar

-----------------
Perceived attractiveness of the face is measured as follows:

"
One's face could look as UNATTRACTIVE as possible.

OR
One's face could look as ATTRACTIVE as possible.
If so, it would be extremely pleasant to look at.

as UNATTRACTIVE as possible ..................................... as ATTRACTIVE as possible

OR

I ideally want my face to look  ________.
as UNATTRACTIVE as possible ..................................... as ATTRACTIVE as possible

OR

I really believe my face looks ________.
as UNFAMILIAR as possible ..................................... as FAMILIAR as possible
"
-----------------

Desired familiarity of the face is measured as follows:
"
One's face could look as UNFAMILIAR as possible.

OR
One's face could look as FAMILIAR as possible.

as UNFAMILIAR as possible ..................................... as FAMILIAR as possible

registration_responses.q19.question:
COPY-PASTED FROM EARLIER

[....
Hypothesis 0 (H0)--so dubbed as it regarded as near self-evident--is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity.

Hypothesis 1 (H1) is that people will strive to verify their facial identity. 

Hypothesis 2 (H2) is that people will strive to enhance their facial identity more than they strive to verify it.

These three hypotheses yield several predictions.

FIRST: as regards the extent to which participants self-reported desire for their face to be attractive and familiar, we predict that they will want it to be more attractive than not (H1), and more familiar than not (H2), but also to want the former more than they want the latter (H3).
...]
================================================
Here, two one-sample t-tests from the scale midpoint, and a within-group t-test, will be applied.
The analyses will be conducted collapsing across the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions, which here do not apply.
================================================


[....
(Moderation: We predict that this will also be the case even when perceptions of facial attractiveness and familiarity are controlled for. In this regard, we do not predict any definite simple correlation between the perception of one's facial attractiveness and the desire to be facially attractive: although a deficiency of facial attractiveness might amplify desire for its, it might also promote a downgrading of facial attractiveness, leading to a "draw". As for the correlation between facial familiarity and desire for facial familiarity, a lack of variation in the former case is liable to constrain correlations to the point of uninformativeness.)
...]
================================================
We will look at all correlations using Pearson 's (more sensitive) and Spearman's (more robust) coefficients. We will compute the four correlations involving these variables, not predicting any to be significant. We will also show that the differences from the scale midpoint in desire to be facially attractive remain significant for participants both above and below the scale midpoint, and/or median, in perceptions of facial attractiveness.
The analyses will be conducted collapsing across the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions, which here do not apply.
================================================

[...(Ancillary: We predict that perceptions of attractiveness will be above the midpoint of the scale*, and, fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will also be above the midpoint of the scale. We also predict, again fairly trivially, that perceptions of familiarity will be higher than perceptions of attractiveness. By default, most faces are surely nearly maximal in familiarity; but the motive to self-enhance is unlikely to be strong enough to convince nearly everyone that they are nearly maximal in attractiveness.)

*Note: We make this prediction more tentatively, as it reflects actual as opposed to ideal self-perceptions.
...]
================================================
Here, one-sample t-tests from the scale midpoint, and a within-group t-test, will again applied.
The analyses will be conducted collapsing across the Absolute Versions and Relative Versions, which here do not apply.
================================================

[...
SECOND: in the Absolute Version of the study, we predict that, in Condition (b), participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive, with familiarity held constant at 100% (H0); and in Condition (a), that participants will move their face to be closer to being Entirely Familiar than it is to being Altogether Unfamiliar, with attractiveness being held constant at 100% (H1). 
...]
================================================
Here, one-sample t-tests from the scale midpoint will again be applied.
================================================

[...
In Condition (c), we also predict that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive (H0). This will demonstrate that, even when antagonized by self-verification strivings (reflected in the trade-off between making their face less familiar as they make it more attractive) self-enhancement strivings persist. 
...]
================================================
Here, a one-sample t-test from the scale midpoint will again be applied.
================================================

[...
At the same time, we predict that facial attractiveness augmentation will be curtailed in Condition (c) relative to Condition (b), thereby demonstrating the operation of self-verification verification strivings over and above self-enhancement strivings. 
...]
================================================
Here, a within-group t-test will again be applied.
================================================

[...
Still, in predicting that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive, we also predict that self-enhancement strivings will dominate self-verification strivings (H2). 
...]
================================================
Here, one-sample t-tests from the scale midpoint will have already been conducted. 
================================================

[...
Finally, we predict that participants will, in Condition (b), move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being Hideously Unattractive than they will, in Condition (a), move their face to be closer to being Entirely Familiar than it is to being Altogether Unfamiliar. This again would also reflect self-enhancement strivings dominating self-verification strivings (H2). 
...]
================================================
Here, a within-group t-test will again be applied.
================================================

[...
THIRD: in the Relative Version of the study, we predict that, in Condition (b), participants will make their face more attractive than As It Is Now (H0). 
...]
================================================
Here, one-sample t-tests from the scale zero-point will be applied.
================================================

[...
We further predict that they will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being As It Is Now (H0). 
...]
================================================
Here, a one-sample t-test from the scale midpoint will again be applied.
================================================

[...
In Condition (c), we also predict that participants will make their face more attractive than it is As It Is Now (H0). This will demonstrate that, even when antagonized by self-verification strivings (reflected in the trade-off between making their face less familiar as they make it more attractive) self-enhancement strivings persist.
...]
================================================
Here, one-sample t-tests from the scale zero-point will again be applied.
================================================

[...
At the same time, we predict that facial attractiveness augmentation will be curtailed in Condition (c) relative to Condition (b), thereby demonstrating the operation of self-verification verification strivings over and above self-enhancement strivings. 
...]
================================================
Here, a within-group t-test will again be applied.
================================================

[...
Still, we still predict that participants will move their face closer to being Amazing Attractive than to being As It Is Now, consistent with self-enhancement strivings dominating self-verification strivings.
...]
================================================
Here, a one-sample t-test from the scale midpoint will again be applied.
================================================


[...
(Moderation 1: We predict that any advantage for self-enhancing strivings above will be more apparent in the Absolute condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is wider, than in the Relative condition, where the facial attractiveness modification range is smaller. If H2 is falsified, then it is more likely to be falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition, or to be more strongly falsified in the Relative Condition than in the Absolute Condition.)
...]
================================================
Here, where the key analysis was previous a one-sample t-test, a between-group t-test will be conducted; and where it was a within-group t-test, a mixed 2 x 2 ANOVA will be conducted.
================================================

[...
(Moderation 2: We predict that that the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings, in the direction of the former, revealed by the main analyses above, will be positively related to participants' self-reported desires for their face to be attractive, and negatively relative to their self-reported desires for their face to be familiar.)
...]
================================================
Here, where the evidence for the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings was a single score [e.g., in Condition (c)], we will linearly regress those scores on the desire for attractiveness and desire for familiarity; where it was a within-group difference [e.g., the difference between scores in Condition (a) and Condition (b); between scores in Condition (a) and Condition (c); or between scores in Condition (b) and Condition (c)], we will do the same, after first computing the relevant within-group difference score.
================================================

[...
(Moderation 3: We predict that self-enhancing strivings will be stronger (i) in women and (ii) in younger people, with such factors possibly combining synergistically. This is because, for evolutionary and lifespan reasons respectively, facial attractiveness has greater normative value for women and younger people. )
...]
================================================
For gender, where the key analysis was previous a one-sample t-test, a between-group t-test will be conducted; and where it was a within-group t-test, a mixed 2 x 2 ANOVA will be conducted. For age, where the evidence for the balance of self-enhancing strivings versus self-verification strivings was a single score [e.g., in Condition (c)], we will linearly regress those scores on age; where it was a within-subject difference [e.g., the difference between scores in Condition (a) and Condition (b); between scores in Condition (a) and Condition (c); or between scores in Condition (b) and Condition (c)], we will do the same, after first computing the relevant within-group difference score.
================================================

attributes.title: Binding and Retrieval of Control states - control decay due to retrieval delay

q1.value: Binding and Retrieval of Control states - control decay due to retrieval delay Replication 2

q3.value:
A commonly found effect in conflict tasks is the congruency sequence effect (CSE; Egner, 2008). This effect is defined by the reduction of congruency effects in post-conflict trials. Two theoretical approaches compete for the explanation of this phenomenon: Control accounts describe the CSE as the result of adaption processes, which regulate the attentional focus to the task-relevant dimension and/or result in the inhibition of task-irrelevant information. In contrast, binding accounts attribute the CSE to the learning of stimulus-response (S-R) combinations. This type of short term associative learning is referred to as binding.  In subsequent trials the partial retrieval of such bound S-R combinations leads to impaired performance in comparison to the complete retrieval of an S-R combination or no retrieval at all.
Recent theories tried to integrate both approaches. So, it is hypothesized that not only S-R combinations can be bound and retrieved, but also the current cognitive state, which would also include the degree of cognitive control currently implemented. There is first evidence indicating that the binding and retrieval of such control states impact on the CSE (Dignath, Johannsen, Hommel, & Kiesel, 2019). 
With this study we want to replicate the first two studies that investigated the decay of control states (OSF Registration: https://osf.io/8thvs and https://osf.io/m8kbt). Our study’s goal is to conceptually replicate those studies. The replication study will be conducted on an online testing environment using jsPsych (de Leeuw, 2015), a library for JavaScript that allows to program web browser based experiments.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that longer time intervals between trials that allow retrieval of control states leads to a decay in the observed SCE .
To be more precise, we expect to observe a reduced SCE in sequential trials with context repetition and a long ITI in between in comparison to sequential trials with context repetition that were intermitted by short ITIs.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No blinding is involved in this study

question.value:
This is a repeated measure design with four within-subject factors: Congruency in the previous trial (congruent vs incongruent), congruency in the current trial (congruent vs incongruent), context repetition (context in current trial equals context in previous trial) and ITI in the current block (long vs short). 
In the experiment the participants will work through eight blocks of 129 trials. A trial consists of a fixation cross (duration: 250ms), a distractor (a number between 3 and 6, displayed either as word or cipher, duration: 139 ms), a blank (nothing displayed, duration: 35 ms), a target (a number between 3 and 6, presentation context identical to the distractor, duration: 139 ms), a response window (nothing displayed, duration: up to 1701 ms) and an blank before the next trial (either 0 or 2750ms). As ITI we define the blank between the trials plus the fixation cross (ITI duration 250ms vs 3000ms). The participants have to respond to the displayed target with the corresponding key “3”, “4”, “5” or “6”. In order to rule out feature integration as a possible SCE explanation we split the stimulus set of four numbers in two subsets, each containing two numbers. Distractor and target are always selected from the same subsets with subsets alternating after every trial. During the presentation of the distractor, the target and the response window a grey frame is shown. This frame is hidden on response, indicating that the response is registered. The duration of the ITI alternates block wise.

Between participants we will randomize the number combinations in the two stimulus subsets (three combinations possible) and the ITI duration of the first experiment block (short vs long).

Within participants we will counterbalance congruency in the previous trial, congruency in the current trial, context in the previous trial, context in the current trial and the stimulus in the current trial (the displayed number) in each block. The stimulus in the first trial is chosen randomly and will not be included in the analysis.

q9.value:
The number combinations in the stimulus subsets and the ITI duration of the first experiment block will be randomized for every subject. We do not expect any effects for those factors.
All participants will go through all within-subject conditions. Trial order will be determined randomly at the beginning of the experiment following the counterbalancing rules.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit our participants via Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/), a platform that connects researcher with people interested to participate in online studies in exchange for money. Those participants can run the experiment online on their private computer. They will be compensated with money. Data collection starts in March 2020.

q15.value: We will determine our sample size using sequential Bayesian hypothesis testing (Schönbrodt, Wagenmakers, Zehetleitner, & Perugini, 2017). Therefore we will increase our sample in steps of 30 participants until a decisive Bayes Factor larger than 6 or smaller than 1/6 is reached. The minimum sample size is 30 participants. We set a maximum sample size of 150. The maximum sample size was based on a power analysis. We opted for a test-power of 1- β = .80, an alpha-error probability of .05 and an effect size of dz = .209 (the effect size found while testing the main hypothesis in the pilot study).

question.value:
Congruency: In the used distractor-target task the distractor is either identical to the target (congruent) or different (incongruent).
Congruency transition: We manipulate the transition of congruency, so we can control the congruency combination of two sequential trials in every case.
Context: We use numbers as stimuli in the task. Those numbers can be displayed either as a word or a cipher.
Context transition: We manipulate the transition of context, so we can control the context combination of two sequential trials in every case.
ITI duration: We manipulate the ITI block wise. The ITI can be either long (3000 ms) or short (250 ms). In comparison to the first experiment the long ITI was extended with the aim to increase the effect.
We will measure the reaction time and accuracy in every trial.

We will analyze the data via Bayesian t-test. The dependent variable is the context modulation of the SCE, which is computed as the difference between the SCE in trials with context repetition and the SCE in trials with context change. The independent variable is the ITI duration. We will use the default prior widths of .707, as defined by the BayesFactor package in R.

q21.value: We will report the one-tailed Bayes Factor BF10. The decisive Bayes Factor in favor of our alternative Hypothesis is 6. The decisive Bayes Factor in favor of the null hypothesis is 1/6

q22.value:
Participants: We will exclude participants with a mean accuracy rate of 25% or lower (random performance). From the remaining sample we will exclude all participants with a mean accuracy rate 3SD under the sample mean.
Trial-Level: The first trial of every block, error trials, post-error trials and trials with RTs deviating 3SDs from the individual cell mean of the described 2x2x2x2x2 factorial design will be excluded from analysis.

q23.value: All data sets with missing data will be excluded from statistical analysis.
