This is a repeated measure design with four within-subject factors: Congruency in the previous trial (congruent vs incongruent), congruency in the current trial (congruent vs incongruent), context repetition (context in current trial equals context in previous trial) and ITI in the current block (long vs short). 
In the experiment the participants will work through eight blocks of 129 trials. A trial consists of a fixation cross (duration: 250ms), a distractor (a number between 3 and 6, displayed either as word or cipher, duration: 139 ms), a blank (nothing displayed, duration: 35 ms), a target (a number between 3 and 6, presentation context identical to the distractor, duration: 139 ms), a response window (nothing displayed, duration: up to 1701 ms) and an blank before the next trial (either 0 or 2750ms). As ITI we define the blank between the trials plus the fixation cross (ITI duration 250ms vs 3000ms). The participants have to respond to the displayed target with the corresponding key “3”, “4”, “5” or “6”. In order to rule out feature integration as a possible SCE explanation we split the stimulus set of four numbers in two subsets, each containing two numbers. Distractor and target are always selected from the same subsets with subsets alternating after every trial. During the presentation of the distractor, the target and the response window a grey frame is shown. This frame is hidden on response, indicating that the response is registered. The duration of the ITI alternates block wise.

Between participants we will randomize the number combinations in the two stimulus subsets (three combinations possible) and the ITI duration of the first experiment block (short vs long).

Within participants we will counterbalance congruency in the previous trial, congruency in the current trial, context in the previous trial, context in the current trial and the stimulus in the current trial (the displayed number) in each block. The stimulus in the first trial is chosen randomly and will not be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will recruit our participants via Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/), a platform that connects researcher with people interested to participate in online studies in exchange for money. Those participants can run the experiment online on their private computer. They will be compensated with money. Data collection starts in March 2020.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Congruency: In the used distractor-target task the distractor is either identical to the target (congruent) or different (incongruent).
Congruency transition: We manipulate the transition of congruency, so we can control the congruency combination of two sequential trials in every case.
Context: We use numbers as stimuli in the task. Those numbers can be displayed either as a word or a cipher.
Context transition: We manipulate the transition of context, so we can control the context combination of two sequential trials in every case.
ITI duration: We manipulate the ITI block wise. The ITI can be either long (3000 ms) or short (250 ms). In comparison to the first experiment the long ITI was extended with the aim to increase the effect.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will measure the reaction time and accuracy in every trial.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will analyze the data via Bayesian t-test. The dependent variable is the context modulation of the SCE, which is computed as the difference between the SCE in trials with context repetition and the SCE in trials with context change. The independent variable is the ITI duration. We will use the default prior widths of .707, as defined by the BayesFactor package in R.

attributes.title: Defending our space: Distinct threats drive minorities’ responses to Latinx growth

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Defending Our Space: Racial Group Position and Minority Responses to Outgroup Growth Manipulation-of-Mediator Experiment

other.value: In our main analyses, we will examine mean attitudes toward racial minorities relative to Whites, and mean perceived discrimination against racial minorities relative to Whites as dependent variables by condition. In addition, we will explore condition effects on attitudes toward and perceived discrimination against each racial group individually.

sample.value:
Based on our previous study of Black participants, a power analysis (Cohen’s d = .438, 80% power, α =.05, two-tailed) generated a sample size of 83 participants per condition. To account for missing data on individual measures, we will collect 400 U.S-born African American participants.

Based on our previous study of Asian participants, a power analysis (Cohen’s d = .238, 80% power, α =.05, two-tailed) generated a sample size of 279 participants per condition. To account for missing data on individual measures, we will collect 1184 East Asian U.S. resident participants.

analyses.value:
We will model each dependent variable as a latent variable using a confirmatory factor analytic framework. This method minimizes measurement error in our outcomes and is consistent with our prior work. We will incorporate theoretically relevant covariates to help sharpen the precision of any emergent results. For Black Americans, these include pretreatment ideology and age (Philpot, 2007; Dawson, 2000). In turn, for Asian Americans, these include pretreatment ideology, nativity, and age (Wong et al., 2011; Lien et al., 2004). (Note: the inclusion of pretreatment ideology as a covariate is for dependent variables that are not ideology.)

First, we will conduct an ordinary least-squares linear regression model to examine the differences on our key dependent variables between our four experimental conditions. We expect a significant main effect of the Latino growth article manipulation, such that participants who read about Latino growth (vs. control) will report an exclusionary reaction (i.e., less favorable attitudes toward racial minorities, less perceived discrimination toward racial minorities, more support for anti-immigration measures, and more conservative political ideology). For the political ideology dependent variable, we will examine levels of ideology (posttreatment ideology) and changes in ideology (posttreatment ideology – pretreatment ideology). 

We expect an interaction between Latino growth article condition and mediator-level condition such that among participants who read about Latino growth, those in the threat reduction condition will report less exclusionary reactions compared to those who did not read the threat reduction information. 

Second, because we are manipulating levels of the threat mediator to demonstrate the causal effect of the threat mediator on exclusionary reactions to Latino growth, we will conduct a moderated mediation model to examine the conditional indirect effect of Latino growth on our dependent variables through threat (Black participants: cultural threat; Asian participants: group-status threat). We expect the Latino growth article condition to predict exclusionary reactions to Latinos (i.e., less favorable attitudes toward racial minorities, less perceived discrimination toward racial minorities, more support for anti-immigration measures, and more conservative political ideology), and that this relationship would be mediated by cultural threat for Black participants and group status threat for Asian participants. We also expect the threat mediator level manipulation to moderate this mediation.

outliers.value:
We will include all participants in the analyses except in specific cases in which participants have missing data. We will drop any items that do not scale well according to established criteria (e.g., weak factor loadings, lack of construct and discriminant validity). This might force us to analyze single items, depending on data availability to scale items. 

We will consider an outlier to be any response to our outcome(s) that is more than 3 standard deviations from its mean. In addition, we will consider outliers those participants who report 10% or more missing values in our outcomes.

We will also analyze our outcomes as latent variables using Mplus (v.8), where we assess the effect of manipulations on our latent dependent variables of interest. We will parallel these results with analyses of our dependent variables as composite scores regressed on dichotomous indicators of our manipulations (with the control as the omitted category). We will report our findings using the most directly interpretable methodology.

dependent.value:
Responses to Latinx growth will be measured with four key dependent variables based on items from previous research (Pérez, Deichert, & Engelhardt, 2019): 1) favorability toward racial minorities, 2) perceived discrimination against racial minorities, 3) support for anti-immigration measures, and 4) self-reported political ideology. 

1) Favorability toward racial minorities: participants will be asked how they feel toward African Americans, Asian Americans, Latinos, and Whites individually and respond on a 7-point scale (1 = very unfavorable, 7 = very favorable). We will compute attitudes toward racial minorities relative to Whites by subtracting mean attitudes toward Whites from mean attitudes toward each racial minority group (Kinder & Kam, 2009). We will combine these indicators into a scale of average favorability toward people of color relative to Whites. 

2) Perceived discrimination toward racial minorities: participants will be asked how much discrimination there is in the United States against African Americans, Asian Americans, Latinos, and Whites individually and respond on a 7-point scale (1 = very little discrimination, 7 = a lot of discrimination). We will compute perceived discrimination against racial minorities relative to Whites by subtracting mean perceived discrimination toward Whites from mean perceived discrimination toward each racial minority group. We will combine these indicators into a scale of average perceived discrimination toward people of color relative to Whites. 

3) Support for anti-immigration measures: participants will be asked how much they support or oppose the four following anti-immigration measures and respond on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly oppose, 7 = strongly support): “Increase the time required for immigrants to become eligible for U.S. citizenship”, “Increase the level of federal resources for arresting undocumented immigrants (i.e., ICE)”, “Renew temporary relief from deportation for undocumented immigrants brought to the U.S. as children (i.e., DACA)”, and “Provide a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants (i.e., DREAM Act)”. The last two measures will be reverse coded, and we will use responses to these items to create a scale of average opposition to immigration. 

4) Self-reported political ideology: pre- and post-manipulation, participants will be asked their political ideology and respond on a 7-point scale (1 = extremely liberal, 7 = extremely conservative). 

Because we are using a mediation design (Baron & Kenny, 1986) to test whether Black Americans’ reaction to Latinx growth is driven by cultural threat and Asian Americans’ reaction to Latinx growth is driven by group status threat, the cultural threat mediator will be measured by asking participants for their perceptions of the cultural standing of Americans: participants will be asked the extent to which being truly American is reflected by “Having been born in America”, “Having lived in America for most of one’s life”, and “Celebrating American holidays” on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). We will take the mean score of responses to these three items to create a scale of average cultural threat.

In turn, the group status threat mediator will be measured by asking participants for their perceptions of the status of immigrants: participants will be asked the extent to which being an immigrant in the United States is reflected by “Having specialized or technical skills”, “Possessing high levels of education”, and “Having high professional ambitions” on a 7-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). We will take the mean score of responses to these three items to create a scale of average group status threat.

conditions.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions in a 2 (article topic: control vs. Latino growth) X 2 (mediator level: control vs. threat reduction) between-subjects factorial design.

Article manipulation: In the control condition, participants will read information from the U.S. Census Bureau about increasing geographic mobility in the United States. In the Latino growth condition, participants will read information from the U.S. Census Bureau about Latino demographic growth in the United States. The threat of Latino growth manipulation will be matched to participant race, such that the Latino growth article that Black participants read will highlight the cultural foreignness of Latinos, while the Latino growth article that Asian participants read will highlight the low status of Latinos. 

Mediator level manipulation: In our prior studies, we found that Black participants’ exclusionary reactions to Latino growth were mediated by their perceptions that the cultural standing of Americans in general is becoming more foreign. In contrast, we found that Asian participants’ exclusionary reactions to Latino growth were mediated by their perceptions that the status of immigrants in general is decreasing. Therefore, we will utilize a manipulation-of-mediator design (Pirlott & MacKinnon, 2016) to demonstrate the causal effect of the threat mediators on our exclusionary reaction dependent variables. We will experimentally manipulate the effect of the mediator by reassuring or not reassuring participants that Latinos do not threaten one’s racial ingroup position. In the control condition, participants read no additional information. In the threat reduction condition, the threat reduction manipulation (i.e., mediator) is matched to participant race, such that Black Americans read that Americans in general remain a largely native-born group, and Asian Americans read that immigrants in general remain a largely high-status group.

hypothesis.value: Are Black and Asian Americans’ exclusionary responses to Latinx population growth driven by distinct threats (cultural threat and group status threat, respectively)? Emerging research suggests that racial minorities are marginalized along two dimensions in America’s racial hierarchy: 1) perceived superiority, the traditional axis in racial hierarchy research (Blumer, 1958); and 2) perceived cultural foreignness  (Kim, 1999; Zou & Cheryan, 2017). Backed by empirical evidence, this framework reveals that Black Americans are perceived as more American than Latinos, while Asian Americans are perceived as superior to Latinos (Zou & Cheryan, 2017; Xu & Lee 2013). Therefore, we hypothesize that Black Americans’ reaction to Latinx growth is mediated by cultural foreignness threat, and Asian Americans’ reaction to Latinx growth is mediated by group status threat.

attributes.title: Potential Effectiveness of Danlou Tablet in Patients with Chronic Stable Angina: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is one of the diseases with the highest morbidity and mortality, also the major public health problem worldwide. The Global Burden of Disease Study 2017 showed that the population of CAD had reached 110 million in 2016. And approximately 8.92 million died of CAD in this year alone. The most common manifestation of CAD is chronic stable angina (CSA) that makes patients suffer a lot. It’s also associated with increased risks of major adverse cardiovascular events, such as cardiovascular mortality, hospitalization for myocardial infarction, or heart failure. Currently, the aims of treatment of CSA are relieving of symptoms and preventing cardiovascular events. The major treatments include drug treatment (beta-receptor blockers, nitrates, calcium channel blockers and antiplatelet agents) and revascularization. However, in 2019 AHA Scientific Sessions, the ISCHEMIA study showed that heart procedures added to taking medicines and making lifestyle changes did not result in a reduced rate of heart attack or death compared with medicines and lifestyle changes alone. In addition, heart procedures did not reduce symptoms appreciably or improve the quality of life compared with medicines and lifestyle changes alone. This allows us to reconsider how to increase the clinical benefits of patients who have already received medication. In China, traditional Chinese medicine therapies are commonly applied in the treatment of CSA, including herbal medicine, acupuncture, Chinese patent medicine.  Clinical studies have established that these therapies can alleviate chest pain, improve cardiac function and quality of life. Danlou tablet (DLT) is one of Chinese patent medicine, which approved by China Food and Drug Administration. It is originated from a TCM prescription named Gualou Xiebai Banxia Decoction recorded in Synopsis of Golden Chamber, which has been used to treat chest pain for more than 2000 years in China. Clinical studies have showed DLT could reduce the frequency and duration of angina pectoris, and improve cardiac function. Besides, several experiments have also validated the effects of DLT in decreasing inflammation, improving myocardial ischemia, protecting vascular endothelium and stabilizing vulnerable plaques. Although several clinical studies have reported the effectiveness of DLT for treating CSA, these studies have not yet been systematically summarized in high quality. Thus, the aims of this review are to examine the evidence of the effect and safety of DLT on CSA and provide recommendations on clinical practice.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Randomized Clinical Trials

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: For this systematic review, the following bibliographic databases were searched for randomized controlled trials published in English-language or Chinese-language from inception to May 2019: PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library databases, China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Wanfang Database, China Scientific Journal Database (VIP) and Chinese Biomedicine (SinoMed). The searching items are chronic stable angina, angina pectoris, coronary artery disease, coronary heart disease, Danlou tablet, Dan lou tablet, dan-lou tablet and random. We searched meeting conference papers and performed manual searches of corresponded bibliographies to collect additional published studies.

q13.value: All the clinical studies that compliance with inclusion criteria

question.value: we manipulated the total efficacy rate by reduction of frequency of angina attack after treatment. 50% reduction of frequency of angina attack , we think it's effective, otherwise it's ineffective.

The primary outcome is the change of frequency of angina attack after treatment,(times per week).
the secondary outcome are: 
change in duration of angina attack after treatment(mins per time), 
use of rescued drugs after treatment, 
efficacy rate, 
adverse events

RevMan 5.3.0 software provided by the Cochrane Collaboration was used to analyze the results. Continuous outcomes were presented as weighted mean difference (WMD), and dichotomous data were presented as relative risk (RR); 95% confidence intervals (CI) were calculated for both. Heterogeneity was assessed with Chi-squared tests. If I2 < 50%, fixed effect model was used for data analysis; If I2 > 50%, then statistical heterogeneity between studies exists, random effect model was used. The possible reasons of heterogeneity were analyzed and the sensitive analysis was conducted.

q21.value: Studies were included if all the following criteria were satisfied: (a) Patients: adults (age≥18 year old) with chronic stable angina; (b) Intervention: Danlou tablet combined with conventional treatment; (c) Comparison: conventional treatment or placebo combined with conventional treatment; (d) Outcomes: change of frequency of angina attack after treatment, change in duration of angina attack after treatment, use of rescued drugs after treatment, efficacy rate, adverse events; (e) Study design: randomized controlled trial (RCT). Conventional treatments include anti-platelets agents, nitrates and statin.

q22.value: Studies were excluded if one of the following criteria was satisfied: (a) Patients: adults with acute coronary syndrome or severe comorbidities and complications; (b) Intervention: with other non-conventional treatment.

registration_responses.q12.question: For this systematic review, the following bibliographic databases were searched for randomized controlled trials published in English-language or Chinese-language from inception to May 2019: PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library databases, China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Wanfang Database, China Scientific Journal Database (VIP) and Chinese Biomedicine (SinoMed). The searching items are chronic stable angina, angina pectoris, coronary artery disease, coronary heart disease, Danlou tablet, Dan lou tablet, dan-lou tablet and random. We searched meeting conference papers and performed manual searches of corresponded bibliographies to collect additional published studies.
registration_responses.q16.question: we manipulated the total efficacy rate by reduction of frequency of angina attack after treatment. 50% reduction of frequency of angina attack , we think it's effective, otherwise it's ineffective.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The primary outcome is the change of frequency of angina attack after treatment,(times per week).
the secondary outcome are: 
change in duration of angina attack after treatment(mins per time), 
use of rescued drugs after treatment, 
efficacy rate, 
adverse events
registration_responses.q19.question: RevMan 5.3.0 software provided by the Cochrane Collaboration was used to analyze the results. Continuous outcomes were presented as weighted mean difference (WMD), and dichotomous data were presented as relative risk (RR); 95% confidence intervals (CI) were calculated for both. Heterogeneity was assessed with Chi-squared tests. If I2 < 50%, fixed effect model was used for data analysis; If I2 > 50%, then statistical heterogeneity between studies exists, random effect model was used. The possible reasons of heterogeneity were analyzed and the sensitive analysis was conducted.

attributes.title: The influence of rewards on incidental memory: more does not mean better

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The influence of rewards on incidental memory: more does not mean better (we explore how the magnitude of rewards affect each other when they were presented in a sequential way.)

sample.value: 30 participants will be recruited to attend this experiment.

analyses.value: A 2 (Image Type:rewarded vs. unrewarded) x 2 (Following Task Type: rewarded vs. unrewarded) ANOVA with the Cohen’s d score as the dependent variable will be utilized in this experiment.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded for not following the task instructions or having memory performance outcomes more than 3 standard deviations below average.

dependent.value: Participants will be instructed to attend a surprise recognition memory test immediately or one day later.  The memory performance was indexed by the Cohen’s d score, calculated by the z score of the hit rates (the percentage of ‘Old’ responses for the ‘Old’ stimuli) minus the z scores of the false alarm rates (the percentage of ‘Old’ responses for the ‘New’ stimuli).

conditions.value: All participants will complete  2 (Image Type:rewarded vs. unrewarded) x 2 (Following Task Type: rewarded vs. unrewarded) conditions in this experiment.

hypothesis.value: Recently, many studies have revealed that rewards promote long-term memory and learning, even in an incidental way. It is still not clear how the reward magnitude influences memory. Thus, in this study, we explore how the magnitude of rewards affect each other when they were presented in a sequential way.
